PERSON: Paul M. Sweezy

HEADLINE: Paul Sweezy, 93, Marxist Publisher and Economist, Dies

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Paul M. Sweezy, a Harvard University economist who left academia and became the nation's leading Marxist intellectual and publisher during the cold war and the McCarthy era, died Saturday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 93.
 The cause was congestive heart failure, his daughter, Lybess Sweezy, said.
 Mr. Sweezy did not think of himself as a Stalinist or sectarian. His Marxism developed as a response to the Great Depression, and his mentor was a famed conservative economist, Joseph Schumpeter, who counted on spirited entrepreneurs to lift the economy through a process of destruction and rebuilding. While Schumpeter wanted less government, Mr. Sweezy wanted more to offset what he considered capitalism's failings. 
 Still, the two men worked together at Harvard in the late 1930's and early 1940's. Schumpeter cited his young friend in several of his own works and endorsed Mr. Sweezy for a tenured professorship at Harvard, even campaigning on his behalf. The slot went to a non-Marxist, and Mr. Sweezy soon left academia. Because of an inheritance from his father, a banker, he had enough money to support himself. Mr. Sweezy later told friends that if he had been forced to work for a living, he might have been more of a conformist.
 Instead, in 1949 he became co-founder and co-editor of The Monthly Review, an independent Marxist journal published in Manhattan that he continued to edit and contribute to until well into the 1990's. The magazine still appears, although its monthly circulation has fallen to 7,000, from 12,000 at its peak in the 1970's. For the first issue, Albert Einstein contributed an article titled ''Why Socialism?'' and over the years the bylines included such famous radicals or Marxists as W. E. B. Du Bois, Jean-Paul Sartre, Che Guevara and Joan Robinson.
 ''The Monthly Review was attractive to people who were leaving the Communist Party and other sectarian groups,'' said John Bellamy Foster, a co-editor of the publication now. ''It was and is Marxist, but did not hew to the party line or get into sectarian struggles.''
 That reflected Mr. Sweezy's approach in the 100 articles or so that he wrote over the years and the more than 20 books he signed as author, co-author or editor. The most famous was ''Monopoly Capital: An Essay on the American Economic and Social Order'' (Monthly Review Press, 1966), with Paul A. Baran as co-author.
 That book argued that unregulated market economies have a tendency to stagnate and to develop oligopolies in which a few companies dominate each industry and keep pushing up prices, fattening profits for the oligopolies but damping economic activity because of a lack of price competition.
 What saved the United States from that fate in the 1960's, the authors wrote, were temporary phenomenon: military spending, robust consumerism and the growing demand for autos because of rapidly expanding suburbs and the new Interstate highway system.
 Paul Marlor Sweezy was born on April 10, 1910, the youngest of three sons of Everett P. Sweezy, vice president of First National Bank of New York, and Caroline Wilson Sweezy. He earned a bachelor's degree from Harvard in 1931 and his Ph.D. in 1937. By then he was a Marxist, having taken that step during a year at the London School of Economics.
 ''I became convinced,'' he wrote much later, ''that mainstream economics of the kind I had been taught at Harvard had little to contribute toward understanding the major events and trends of the 20th century.''
 Still, back at Harvard, as a graduate student and then an instructor, he came in contact with Schumpeter and a friendship flourished, although they supported different solutions for ending the Depression. For Schumpeter, President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal measures suppressed entrepreneurs in their normal process of creative destruction and innovation.
 For Mr. Sweezy, who borrowed from Keynesian theory as well as Marxism, government planning and intervention had a role, although working people also had to intervene. Listening to their debates, Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate, spoke of Schumpeter as ''the foxy Merlin'' and Mr. Sweezy as the ''young Sir Galahad'' who early on ''established himself as among the most promising economists of his generation.''
 During World War II, Mr. Sweezy spent four years in the Army as an officer in the Office of Strategic Services. After returning briefly to Harvard as a teacher and having failed to gain a tenured position, he left in 1946 to pursue the goal of establishing ''a serious and authentic American brand of Marxism.''
 The pursuit was not easy in the McCarthy era. He found himself in the courts in the 1950's after he refused to turn over to the attorney general of New Hampshire his notes from a lecture at the University of New Hampshire. The attorney general accused him of subversive activities and the case eventually went to the United States Supreme Court, which ruled in Mr. Sweezy's favor.
 Mr. Sweezy's first wife, Nancy, and his second wife, Zirel, survive, as do three children, Samuel, Lybess and Martha; two stepchildren, Jeffrey and Jennifer Dowd; seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Like Japan in the 1980's, China Poses Big Economic Challenge

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: GUANGZHOU, China 

 BODY:
When Japan, at the zenith of its economic power, built a huge airport in Osaka in the late 1980's, the project set off a seven-year trade battle with the United States over the nearly complete exclusion of non-Japanese companies.
 China, Japan's heir as Asia's rising star, is now completing its own immense airport here in Guangzhou, the sprawling commercial center of affluent southeastern China. But the Chinese are going about it differently.
 American companies designed the terminal, its air-conditioning system and the flight information system. A German company engineered the vaulting roof, a Danish company produced the boarding gates and a Dutch company, the check-in counters. Chinese women in broad-brimmed straw hats wield shovels and brooms across from a modern air-traffic-control tower designed by a company from Singapore. 
 The welcome that China is offering to multinational companies and foreign investment has left many Western business executives so critical of a closed Japan more than a decade ago, enthusiastically embracing China, its cheap work force and its huge markets. 
 But that same openness -- combined with China's vast population of 1.3 billion and military muscle -- makes it an even greater long-term economic challenge to the United States than Japan seemed to be in the 1980's, according to a growing number of executives, economists and officials.
 While China's economy is still one-third the size of Japan's, the potential size of its market has made it very hard for companies to say no when Beijing officials demand that they build factories, transfer the latest technology or adopt Chinese technical standards.
 Japan has effectively run out of low-wage workers for its industries, and it quickly brought much of its economy up to and in some cases beyond Western technological standards. China still has vast reserves of cheap labor in inland areas and many backward industries that can grow swiftly as they copy Western and Japanese methods.
 ''China could do what Japan did, as a very fast follower, but China could do it bigger and better and for a longer period of time,'' said Steven Weber, an Asia scholar at the University of California at Berkeley. ''It's not necessarily as vulnerable as Japan was.''
 But while Japan's danger to other economies over the last decade has taken the forms of economic stagnation and political lassitude, China poses the risk of fast, sharp shocks. 
 Its transition from a planned economy to a form of capitalism seems to make it especially susceptible to economic booms and busts, and Chinese officials have begun worrying that an unsustainable economic bubble is developing. At the same time, China's one-party system may struggle to adapt to the social tensions brought to the surface by rapid economic development.
 Optimists see it surmounting such obstacles. ''Once China passes the high growth, it will have the bursting of the bubble,'' said Eisuke Sakakibara, Japan's former vice minister of finance for international affairs, ''but that will happen in 20 years. China is Japan of the 1960's.''
 Others express greater caution. David Cunningham, the president of Asian and Pacific operations at Fed-Ex, said the company was considering the new Guangzhou airport as the site of an Asian hub, somewhat like its Memphis operations. FedEx is watching China's growth carefully.
 ''What could be devastating is if the global business-investing person becomes burned or disillusioned and takes their investment elsewhere, and today it can happen at the click of a finger; ask Southeast Asia about it,'' Mr. Cunningham said, referring to the Asian financial crisis of 1997-98. The region is still recovering.
 Like the Japanese challenge of a generation ago, China's strength is drawing growing attention in American politics. Senator John Edwards of North Carolina has become the main challenger to Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts for the Democratic presidential nomination by emphasizing jobs lost to trade, especially trade with China; Mr. Kerry says he and Mr. Edwards essentially agree on trade questions. 
 The Bush administration over the last year has tried to assuage worries about job losses by talking tough with the Chinese -- in particular, demanding that China let the exchange value of its currency float upward to raise the price of its exports. But it has also continued to assert its faith in a policy of free trade.
 China's strengths are indeed impressive. Its wage advantage is much greater than Japan's was a decade or two ago. China has the diplomatic muscle to resist trade and currency concessions that might undermine its competitive edge. And its opening to foreign investment brings China the latest technology and the corporate connections overseas that help it fight curbs on its exports.
 For all these reasons, China's trade surplus with the United States has soared, quintupling in the last decade to $124 billion in 2003. By comparison, Japan's surplus did not quite triple in the decade when its economy conjured the most anxiety among Americans. And in the last decade, it has leveled off, at $66 billion last year.
 China's biggest competitive advantage, its immense and low-paid work force, is on view here in the southeast, at places like the BBK Electronics Corporation's air-conditioned factory in Dongguan, a two-hour drive from the new Guangzhou airport.
 Sun Xin, 20, is one of nearly 4,000 employees, most sitting on backless stools at counters under fluorescent lights, as they snap and screw together fairly sophisticated portable and countertop DVD players. Wearing a blue company baseball hat and a company-issued shirt, she works 8 to 11 hours a day stuffing power cords, remote controls and other DVD accessories into plastic bags. 
 Du Anan, an identically dressed 18-year-old on the other side of the counter, then tapes the bags shut.
 Like most of the workers, Ms. Sun and Ms. Du are migrants, having each taken a 30-hour ride aboard slow Chinese trains from their impoverished villages in north central China. Each earns $60 to $75 a month, a pittance by American standards but a lot in rural China, where 200 million people live on less than $1 a day.
 ''There is nothing to do at home,'' Ms. Sun said. ''I came here to learn to do more myself.''
 She and Ms. Du live in factory dormitories and say they rarely venture out. But the women express the same excitement, in almost the same words, about having come even to a grimy, smoggy city like Dongguan. ''I want to see the outside world,'' Ms. Du said. 
 China has 10 times the population of Japan, with more unemployed adults in rural areas than the entire American work force. Raising the wages of so many people to the levels of industrial nations will take a long time.
 Through the 1970's and 80's, Japanese wages rose 70 percent faster than American wages, according to data from the International Labor Organization. That, together with rapid appreciation in the value of the yen, helped push up Japanese factory wages from one-third of American levels to rough parity.
 Chinese wages, though, were no more than 4 percent of American and Japanese wages in 2002, the most recent year available. While official Chinese statistics show that wages doubled from 1996 to 2002, some factory owners say that pay has been flat, or even declined slightly in recent years, as rural migrants continue to pour into the cities.
 In the meantime, the productivity gap is being closed by a rapid investment in infrastructure as China puts a third of the world's steel production and half its cement into extending modern roads, power grids and telecommunications links across the country.
 BBK Electronics is an example of how China has benefited from opening up to the global economy. Money from Taiwan and Russia, as well as local Chinese money, helped build the company's factory seven years ago, said Louis Leung, the marketing manager, and BBK now makes many devices sold in the United States under the Memorex, Philco and Lafayette brand names.
 If Japan profited handsomely from selling videocassette recorders two decades ago, China is coming to dominate the production of the next generation of DVD technology. BBK started by licensing technology from Sony, but it now has 300 researchers coming up with refinements, Mr. Leung said. On a laptop computer, he plays a company presentation that ends with BBK's two long-term goals: ''to realize modernization'' and ''to challenge Sony.''
 Japan rapidly caught up with the West by licensing technology from companies like Caterpillar that failed to foresee the risk of Japanese competitors like Komatsu. But China has both licensed technology and used the potential of a huge market to lure foreign investment.
 That has not only brought further investment but until recently has also helped insulate China from trade clashes. Many of the same multinationals that once fought with the Japanese, like the Detroit automakers, are now big investors in China -- investors that oppose trade restrictions on it.
 But as the Chinese work to build industrial cornerstones like the auto and semiconductor industries, this may change. Nor has China avoided some trade conflicts. Executives in many industries describe China as more open to imports than Japan, but still not nearly so open as the United States. From soybeans to commercial banking, American businesses complain that China has thrown up regulatory barriers that limit their ability to compete.
 Daryl Hatano, vice president for public policy at the Semiconductor Industry Association in San Jose, Calif., said his group might ask Washington to file a protest with the World Trade Organization if China did not halt its practice of charging taxes as low as 3 percent for domestically produced computer chips, compared with 17 percent for imported chips.
 Even with those taxes, imported chips hold 85 percent of the Chinese market; by comparison, it took tense negotiations in 1986 for President Ronald Reagan's administration to win an agreement giving foreign manufacturers a goal of 20 percent of the Japanese market; by 1995, the sales rose to 30 percent.
 So far, the Bush administration has limited its Chinese trade cases to fairly small categories of exports like brassieres, a few kinds of furniture and color television sets.
 In part, analysts say, Washington chooses to act gingerly out of geopolitical considerations. China is a nuclear power that, unlike Japan, does not depend on the United States for military protection. Yet the United States looks to Beijing for help in coping with problems in countries including North Korea and Pakistan. So while American officials can press the Chinese to let the yuan float, they cannot press as hard as they did with Japan in 1986, when Tokyo was spurred into letting its currency rise sharply against the dollar, eroding its exports' competitiveness.
 ''Washington is concerned about China setting its own agenda,'' said John S. Chen, the Hong Kong-born chairman and chief executive of Sybase, an American software company that has expanded aggressively in both Japan and China. ''The Japanese were more friendly.''
 The biggest question lingering over China is how vulnerable it remains to acute setbacks -- a banking failure, an inflationary spiral, even a temporary economic bust. Citing overcapacity and excessive investment in some sectors of the economy, the Chinese central bank warned recently that ''we really cannot be optimistic about the situation of inflation.'' A crack in the economy could shake governments across East Asia that have tied their economies to China's, warns Ajay Kapur, a strategist in Hong Kong with Salomon Smith Barney. 
 For a parable about economies that seem as if they could prosper indefinitely, Chinese officials need look no farther than to Osaka and its huge airport. The artificial island on which it was built a few years ago is slowly sinking in the Pacific.

HEADLINE: Many Return to Lap of Luxury With No Tight Belts

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY

 BODY:
David Falk, the sports agent, recounts this story about Michael Jordan, one of his clients. The owner of a hockey team was recently telling him and Mr. Jordan about a technology entrepreneur whose net worth had plunged to $50 million from about $1 billion in the dot-com crash. ''Michael looked at him horrified and said to me, 'Does that mean he has to fly commercial now?''' Mr. Falk recalled.
 Not likely. Living high on the hog is very much back in vogue in business travel these days, for both the rich and not so rich.
 After several lean years, corporate-jet travel is recovering. Five-star hotels are proliferating as the big chains rush to establish their brands in cities where the higher-ranking corporate employees, who are often acutely aware of the cachet a certain hotel brand carries, are able to spend top dollar while traveling on business. 
 ''We get very little price resistance,'' said Simon F. Cooper, the president and chief operating officer of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company, which operates 55 hotels worldwide and has entered a venture to open new five-star hotels branded with Bulgari, the Italian luxury jeweler. 
 Like other American-based chains, including Hyatt International, Ritz-Carlton is growing in a widening market. ''We've expanded very strongly in North America,'' Mr. Cooper said.
 Other markets with big growth potential are China and the rest of Asia, as well as Europe and the Middle East. ''We need to be in Cairo; we need a much larger hotel in Dubai; we should be in Beirut,'' Mr. Cooper said.
 International travel is also a robust luxury market for airlines. Two weeks ago, Virgin Atlantic Airways, a unit of the Virgin Group, opened a 7,000-square-foot clubhouse in Terminal 4 at Kennedy International Airport for passengers flying its new upper-class suite service, which features individual cubicles with flat-bed seats that have mattresses.
 Most airline lounges are hidden behind oak doors, but this one is partly open on a mezzanine, easily seen by the people below, in what a Virgin Atlantic executive called an ''aspirational'' marketing ploy. 
 Virgin Atlantic's archrival, British Airways, recently expanded its flat-bed business-class service to flights between Atlanta and Gatwick Airport in London, while ridiculing the ''increasingly dowdy BusinessElite cabins'' of Delta Air Lines.
 In the last two years, more than a dozen foreign and domestic airlines with international service in the United States have spent more than $1 billion on flat-bed seating, in-cabin lounges and other luxuries to grab a share of the international business-class market. This segment began rebounding late last year as corporate travel budgets relaxed and fares on long-haul routes moderated. 
 ''If people are going to spend the money, they want to be on an airline where they know they're going to be comfortable,'' said Robert Laney, the president of 1st-Air, which sells discounted international business-class seats. He said the company's bookings were up 20 percent in the first six weeks of this year from a year earlier, ''about where we were in 2001.''
 Of course, just as in the American economy at large, the gap between the haves and the have-nots is growing in the area of business travel.
 Mr. Falk is unabashedly one of the haves. He recently upgraded his business jet from a midsize seven-seat Learjet 60, with a range of about 2,500 miles, to a new ''super midsize'' Bombardier Challenger 300, which seats eight and has a 3,100-mile range.
 ''Before, most of my travel was trips of about two and a half hours, so that was a good size for me,'' said Mr. Falk, who owns a 200-hour-a-year share of the plane -- in which he says he is usually the only passenger -- through Bombardier's Flexjet fractional-share program. ''But now, I've started to make some movies, and I go to L.A. once a month. So the 300 is now the perfect size for me.''
 But it is not just the superrich who are flying high these days.
 Though sales of corporate jets have declined significantly since 2001, increasing numbers of businesspeople are riding domestically on fancy business jets through fractional-share programs or an expanding range of luxury air-charter operations that market themselves as a comfortable, time-efficient alternative to the commercial airlines. 
 At the same time, some commercial airlines are making a grab for the growing numbers of business-jet customers.
 Last year, for example, Delta Air Lines started Delta AirElite, a luxury charter service that uses 400 business jets throughout the country. And a new charter venture called Tomlin Air began operating last month using Gulfstream III business jets on shuttle routes between Boston, New York and Washington.
 Later this month, Tomlin -- which has three Gulfstream III's and a Gulfstream IV -- plans to start operating luxury charter flights between New York and Los Angeles, said Daniel S. Leon, the company's president. The fare: $4,800 each way. 
 ''You can buy a first-class seat on a commercial flight for maybe $3,000,'' Mr. Leon said. ''But a lot of people are fed up'' with commercial airlines, he said. Even with luxury charter fares more than three times as expensive, ''there is a definite market out there.'' 
 Of course, luxury travel is not what most business travelers experience, especially domestically. After mid-2001, when the economy soured, the tightening of corporate budgets shunted many executives onto cramped low-cost airlines, while money-losing mainstream airlines simultaneously cut service and comforts. However, many frequent fliers who remained with the major airlines became accustomed to flying first class. 
 Today, first-class domestic cabins are usually filled almost exclusively with passengers who paid coach fares but were upgraded through airline loyalty programs.
 As more business travelers become accustomed to the comforts of traveling in luxury and grow more disenchanted with commercial air travel, the business-jet industry is grabbing their attention with popular new products like charter networks and plans that allow the purchase of jet time by the hour.
 One result is that more corporate travel departments are shifting at least a portion of their travel to business jets, often as a way to fill gaps in the retrenching commercial air system.
 ''We're seeing a lot of people now saying, 'Well, I don't really have to decide between whether I'm going to be Zsa Zsa Gabor or Joe Sixpack when I travel; I'm going to use this when it makes sense and use it efficiently and smartly,''' said Trevor Cornwell, vice president for strategy and business development at Bombardier. ''It's on a trip like when you get to California and you still have three or four hops to make that this begins to look very good as an option.''
 And though business-jet orders and deliveries have slumped since their peak three years ago, Honeywell predicts a gradual recovery in orders this year and an expansion in deliveries next year. 
 Mr. Falk, the sports agent, said that while flying his own business jet is ''very expensive,'' it makes sense as a time-saver. 
 ''I live in Washington, and when I'd go to New York I used to say, 'Should I spent $200 on the shuttle or $2,000 on a private jet?''' he said. ''A few times, I'd take the shuttle, end up waiting on the runway at La Guardia for two hours, and I'd curse myself out for being cheap. So I just made up my mind I was going to spend a certain amount of money every year to travel.
 ''I am not an extravagant person,'' Mr. Falk insisted. ''But once you start doing this, it's very difficult to go back.''

HEADLINE: HSBC Says Profit Jumped 41% in 2003

BYLINE: By HEATHER TIMMONS

DATELINE: LONDON, March 1 

 BODY:
HSBC Holdings, the world's second-largest bank, on Monday reported an increase of almost 41 percent in profit in 2003, buoyed by its purchase of the consumer lender Household International in the United States. 
 Executives used Monday's earnings announcement to revisit the bank's plans to increase its investment banking business. HSBC, whose notoriously thrifty chairman, Sir John Bond, has in the past derided the expenses and salaries associated with investment banking, plans to continue to expand in the sector this year, particularly in the mergers advisory and equity businesses, the bank executives said. 
 The far-flung bank, which lags only Citigroup in market capitalization within the financial services sector, earned $8.77 billion in 2003, a 40.5 percent increase from the year before. Pretax profit was up 33 percent, to $12.8 billion, and revenue increased 54 percent, to $41.1 billion. 
 HSBC has made a big push into North America, buying the Mexican bank Grupo Financiero Bital in 2002 and Household International last year. About 70 percent of the increase in pretax profit for the year stemmed from those acquisitions, with four-fifths of that percentage, or $1.8 billion, from Household alone. 
 ''The Household acquisition has been great for them,'' said Alan Beaney, fund manager with Principal Investment Management in Sevenoaks, England, which specializes in British stocks. By buying Household, which makes loans to people with poor credit histories, HSBC made the company more profitable immediately, because HSBC's AAA credit rating slashed Household's cost of financing.
 HSBC has had a mercurial relationship with investment banking in recent years. In early 2002, the bank decimated its business by telling bankers and analysts in the unit that there would be no bonuses because 2001 had been such a poor year. Dozens of employees left. But in June 2003, the bank hired John Studzinski of Morgan Stanley, and it has slowly been adding bankers since. 
 HSBC said on Monday that it earned $4.44 billion in pretax profit from corporate and investment banking in 2003, a 14 percent increase from the year before.
 ''Our advisory revenues are growing, and we are investing in that business,'' Douglas Flint, the bank's finance director, said during a news conference. The bank is ''encouraged by the number of senior experienced bankers that want to join us,'' he said. 
 Sir John, who is so cost-conscious he travels coach on business flights under three hours, said on Monday that HSBC planned to pick up investment banking business from its existing corporate loan and bond customers. 
 But analysts and investors say there may still be too great a culture clash between HSBC's thrifty style and the high-risk, high-salaried world of investment banking. ''That is probably the weakest bit of their strategy,'' Mr. Beaney said. 
 HSBC's top banker made $:12.6 million ($23.5 million) in 2003, the company said Monday, or about six times Sir John's salary. Within the bank there's ''quite a good understanding that some people get paid more than others,'' particularly in trading and investment banking, Sir John said.
 The bank has no plans to buy a competitor to get into the business, he added. ''Taking over an investment bank is one of the riskiest things we could do,'' Sir John said. 
 In 2004, HSBC expects to expand geographically. ''China, India, Brazil and Mexico will become increasingly important to the global economy,'' Sir John said.

 BODY:

Experts See Risks as China Asserts Economic Power
As China increasingly welcomes multinational companies and foreign investment, many Western business executives have become positively enraptured by the company's cheap work force and its huge markets.
 But that same openness -- combined with China's vast population and military muscle -- makes it an even bigger long-term economic challenge to the United States than Japan seemed to be in the 1980's, according to a growing number of executives, economists and officials. [Page A1.]

Changes on Enron Task Force
Leslie R. Caldwell, who has headed the Justice Department's task force investigating the collapse of Enron, is stepping down to pursue a job in the private sector. Her longtime deputy, Andrew Weissmann, will oversee the task force. Other prominent prosecutors on the task force are also moving on as its primary responsibilities shift from investigating potential crimes to trying to prove criminal charges in court. [C10.]

Effort to Unseat Eisner Continues
Two former Walt Disney directors pursued their campaign to oust Michael D. Eisner, Disney's chairman and chief executive. The action took place as the company's annual meeting is set to take place tomorrow. [C13.]

Yahoo to Charge for Web Listings
Yahoo said yesterday that it would start charging money for companies that want to improve the ways that their Web sites are listed in its search engine, using a controversial practice called paid inclusion. [C4.]

Oracle Takes Case to Customers
Oracle took the case for its $9.4 billion hostile takeover of PeopleSoft directly to a group of PeopleSoft corporate customers after the Justice Department's decision last week to sue Oracle to block the deal. [C4.]

An Encouraging Sign on Jobs
United States manufacturers may finally be close to adding jobs after 42 consecutive months of layoffs, a survey released yesterday suggested, but they also face escalating pricing pressures that could squeeze profits. [C17.]

Stocks Rise on Economic News
Stocks rose on positive job news from manufacturers. The Dow jumped 94.22 points, to 10,678.14. The Nasdaq rose 27.98 points, to 2,057.80. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 11.03, at 1,155.97. [C13.]

Sprint Is Seen as Primed for a Deal
By moving over the weekend to combine its wireless tracking stock with the stock of its traditional phone operations, Sprint has helped stoke anticipation on Wall Street that it is preparing to join in the consolidation of the telecommunications industry by becoming either an acquirer or a takeover target. That may not be what Gary Forsee, Sprint's chief executive, intended. Mr. Forsee has gone out of his way recently to say that Sprint is well positioned to compete as a stand-alone company. [C10.]

20 Are Arrested in Hong Kong
Investigators have arrested 20 people in Hong Kong in a financial scandal involving accusations of bribery and rigging of share prices by corporate executives, fund managers, a research analyst and a securities broker. [World Business, Section W.]

Oscar Ads Trump Super Bowl's
The Super Bowl is supposed to be the biggest day of the year for advertising, but when measured against the Academy Awards this year, it seems, well, hobbit-size. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C6.]

Showing Attitude at the Airport
Airline passengers showing an ''offensive attitude'' at an airport security screening station could be subject to a fine from the Transportation Security Administration. But what about the attitude of the person doing the screening? Joe Sharkey: On the Road. [C9.]

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Outlines Risk in Yuan Policy

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
China should shore up its ''quite weak'' banking system to prevent instability as it moves toward floating the yuan's value against the dollar, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has told a United States senator.
 China needs to improve banks' internal controls by giving local managers more training and authority, Mr. 
Greenspan wrote. He was responding to questions posed at a Feb. 12 hearing by Richard Shelby, chairman of the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs. 
 To float its currency, China would also have to lift capital controls, allowing domestic investors to pull money from the local banking system. Such action might ''cause an outflow of deposits from Chinese banks, destabilizing the system,'' Mr. Greenspan wrote to Senator Shelby, Republican of Alabama. ''Financial instability in a major emerging market economy such as China would present a risk to the global economic outlook.'' 
 In a speech last Friday, Mr. Greenspan said a revaluation of the yuan was a ''fairly reasonable expectation'' and an increase in productivity in China ''will drive the exchange rate upward.''

HEADLINE: Maestro of Chutzpah

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN. 
E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
The traditional definition of chutzpah says it's when you murder your parents, then plead for clemency because you're an orphan. Alan Greenspan has chutzpah.
 Last week Mr. Greenspan warned of the dangers posed by budget deficits. But even though the main cause of deficits is plunging revenue -- the federal government's tax take is now at its lowest level as a share of the economy since 1950 -- he opposes any effort to restore recent revenue losses. Instead, he supports the Bush administration's plan to make its tax cuts permanent, and calls for cuts in Social Security benefits. 
 Yet three years ago Mr. Greenspan urged Congress to cut taxes, warning that otherwise the federal government would run excessive surpluses. He assured Congress that those tax cuts would not endanger future Social Security benefits. And last year he declined to stand in the way of another round of deficit-creating tax cuts.
 But wait -- it gets worse.
 You see, although the rest of the government is running huge deficits -- and never did run much of a surplus -- the Social Security system is currently taking in much more money than it spends. Thanks to those surpluses, the program is fully financed at least through 2042. The cost of securing the program's future for many decades after that would be modest -- a small fraction of the revenue that will be lost if the Bush tax cuts are made permanent.
 And the reason Social Security is in fairly good shape is that during the 1980's the Greenspan commission persuaded Congress to increase the payroll tax, which supports the program.
 The payroll tax is regressive: it falls much more heavily on middle- and lower-income families than it does on the rich. In fact, according to Congressional Budget Office estimates, families near the middle of the income distribution pay almost twice as much in payroll taxes as in income taxes. Yet people were willing to accept a regressive tax increase to sustain Social Security.
 Now the joke's on them. Mr. Greenspan pushed through an increase in taxes on working Americans, generating a Social Security surplus. Then he used that surplus to argue for tax cuts that deliver very little relief to most people, but are worth a lot to those making more than $300,000 a year. And now that those tax cuts have contributed to a soaring deficit, he wants to cut Social Security benefits. 
 The point, of course, is that if anyone had tried to sell this package honestly -- ''Let's raise taxes and cut benefits for working families so we can give big tax cuts to the rich!'' -- voters would have been outraged. So the class warriors of the right engaged in bait-and-switch.
 There are three lessons in this tale.
 First, ''starving the beast'' is no longer a hypothetical scenario -- it's happening as we speak. For decades, conservatives have sought tax cuts, not because they're affordable, but because they aren't. Tax cuts lead to budget deficits, and deficits offer an excuse to squeeze government spending.
 Second, squeezing spending doesn't mean cutting back on wasteful programs nobody wants. Social Security and Medicare are the targets because that's where the money is. We might add that ideologues on the right have never given up on their hope of doing away with Social Security altogether. If Mr. Bush wins in November, we can be sure that they will move forward on privatization -- the creation of personal retirement accounts. These will be sold as a way to ''save'' Social Security (from a nonexistent crisis), but will, in fact, undermine its finances. And that, of course, is the point.
 Finally, the right-wing corruption of our government system -- the partisan takeover of institutions that are supposed to be nonpolitical -- continues, and even extends to the Federal Reserve.
 The Bush White House has made it clear that it will destroy the careers of scientists, budget experts, intelligence operatives and even military officers who don't toe the line. But Mr. Greenspan should have been immune to such pressures, and he should have understood that the peculiarity of his position -- as an unelected official who wields immense power -- carries with it an obligation to stand above the fray. By using his office to promote a partisan agenda, he has betrayed his institution, and the nation.

HEADLINE: Fearing That a Gap Will Become a Chasm

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1 

 BODY:
When Alan Greenspan urged Congress last week to cut future benefits in Social Security and Medicare, sending elected officials to the barricades, he was if anything understating the magnitude of the problems ahead. Today's budget deficits are measured in the hundreds of billions, but the looming shortfalls for the two retirement programs are projected to be in the tens of trillions of dollars.
 The Bush administration has estimated that the gap between promises under current law and the revenues expected will total $18 trillion over the next 75 years. But an internal study in 2002 by the Treasury Department, looking much further ahead, concluded that the gap was actually $44 trillion -- and would climb each year that nothing was done.
 Indeed, the numbers are so big and extend so far into the future that they border on the surreal. Analysts in both Congress and the administration warn that the flood of retiring baby boomers will cause federal spending on old-age benefits to eventually consume as much of the nation's economy as the entire federal budget does now. And while the problems would be acute even if today's federal budget were balanced, the budget deficits that seem likely for the rest of the decade make matters worse. That is because the government is borrowing more than $200 billion a year from the Social Security and Medicare trust funds to finance its operating deficits. 
 In theory, the two giant trust funds are accumulating huge surpluses that can be used to pay for benefits when the baby boomers retire and the systems start taking in less than they are paying out. In practice, those surpluses are being spent, and the government will probably have to borrow enormous sums to meet its obligations to retirees.
 ''It is time to start telling people the truth,'' said Laurence Kotlikoff, a professor of economics at Boston University and a longtime analyst of the issue. ''Suggesting that some minor adjustments to Social Security will solve the problem is doing a disservice.''
 Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, provoked a political tempest when he told members of the House Budget Committee last week that Congress needed to trim future Social Security and Medicare benefits to head off a fiscal calamity in decades to come.
 Mr. Greenspan proposed adjustments in how the government increases benefits to keep up with inflation and suggested pushing back retirement ages to better reflect increased life expectancy. 
 Democrats immediately attacked the proposed cuts, saying they would be unnecessary if President Bush had not been running up large annual budget deficits just before millions of baby boomers reach retirement age.
 ''Cutting Social Security benefits is not the way to rein in the irresponsible Bush budget deficit,'' chided Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate Democratic leader.
 President Bush and Republican lawmakers distanced themselves as well, saying that much of the problem could be averted by setting up private savings accounts. 
 But as precarious and uncertain as long-range forecasts are, most experts agree that the combined challenges of Social Security and Medicare are too big to be addressed without politically painful remedies.
 The number of retirees is expected to soar from about 40 million today to more than 76 million by 2030, which means that fewer dollars will be coming in from payroll taxes and many more dollars will be going out in retirement and medical benefits. 
 The oldest baby boomers turn 65 in 2011, and by one estimate a husband and wife who retire that year are likely to collect $700,000 in benefits before they die. 
 Trustees of the Medicare and Social Security funds predict that the two programs will run surpluses of more than $200 billion a year for at least the next decade. But the Medicare trust fund will start running deficits in 2013 and run out of money by 2026. Starting in 2018, the Social Security System starts paying out more than it takes in and will have to dip into its trust fund. By 2044, the trust fund will be exhausted. 
 Most experts say the problems of Social Security are much smaller and more predictable than those of Medicare, because retirement formulas are fairly simple and the cost of benefits depends primarily on demographic trends that are quite predictable.
 But Medicare's condition is more ominous, because medical costs have been rising much faster than the overall rate of inflation and the demand for health care is expected to soar as the baby boomers retire.
 The Bush administration estimated last year that Medicare's obligations would be more than $10 trillion over the next 75 years. But that was before President Bush signed the law that will add prescription drug benefits to Medicare -- which the administration now predicts will cost $540 billion over the next 10 years. The costs would climb rapidly after that, as the number of elderly people soars. The Congressional Budget Office has predicted that the new program could cost as much as $2 trillion in its second decade.
 Mr. Bush and many administration officials contend that much of Social Security's problems could be solved by letting people divert some of their payroll contributions to private investment accounts they might manage for themselves.
 But some experts say that the government would have to borrow as much as $1 trillion over the next several decades to make up for the lost revenues and pay retirees benefits earned under the old system.
 And the Congressional Budget Office, in a report on privatization plans last year, said none of the proposals would have much effect.
 ''Using government resources to buy stocks and bonds, without other spending and tax changes, would not automatically lead to an increase in the nation's pool of investment resources,'' the budget office concluded. ''There is no such thing as a free lunch.''
 Some experts contend that even the administration's chilling projections about the looming problems of Social Security seriously understate the problem.
 In 2002, two senior economists at the Treasury Department were asked by Paul H. O'Neill, then the Treasury secretary, to come up with a comprehensive estimate of the federal government's long-term fiscal problems. The total, calculated Kent Smetters, then a deputy assistant secretary for economic policy, and Jagadessh Gokhale, an economist on loan to the Treasury from the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, was an almost unthinkable $44 trillion. 
 That projection was swiftly disavowed by the administration. Rob Nichols, a spokesman for the Treasury Department, said the White House never intended to use the study in its official budget forecast. ''They were doing what they called an independent paper,'' he said. 
 Mr. Gokhale, now a senior fellow at the Cato Institute, a policy research group in Washington, recalled matters differently. ''At some point, late in the game, it was decided that it wouldn't be in the budget,'' he said. ''In my opinion, if they had reported these numbers, they would have gotten a lot of credit.''
 Professor Kotlikoff of Boston University has devised a ''menu of pain'' to lay out different ways of bridging the gap. The choices range from an immediate increase in federal income taxes of 69 percent to an immediate cut in Social Security and Medicare benefits of 45 percent. 
 And those numbers may be too low, he said, because even the disavowed Treasury estimate for the shortfall may be too low. Adding in the new prescription drug program, he said, the imbalance is closer to $51 trillion.
 Whether one accepts the administration's forecast or that of the disavowed study, everyone agrees that the potential problems with Social Security and Medicare dwarf the short-term problems of balancing the budget.
 ''The issue is entitlements,'' said N. Gregory Mankiw, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers. ''That is a huge challenge, but it would be a challenge even if we had a balanced budget today.''

HEADLINE: Mexican Immigrants

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Re ''The Americano Dream'' (column, Feb. 24): 
 Underpinning David Brooks's enlightened reading of assimilation in America is an important recognition that Mexican immigration has strengthened the social and cultural vitality and economic growth of the United States. 
 Regardless of their migratory status, law-abiding, hard-working and taxpaying Mexicans in the United States have chosen to make this their new home. The great majority go through enormous pains to assimilate while maintaining their cultural identity as a means to mitigate the segregation and racism that some of them still face here.
 Today, Mexicans and Mexican-Americans live in all corners of the United States. They participate in all walks of life; they need new opportunities, not renewed prejudices, to continue becoming an integral part of this great country.
 Mr. Brooks has set the tone for a responsible debate untainted by xenophobia or political and partisan gain.

ARTURO SARUKHAN
Consul General of Mexico
New York, Feb. 24, 2004

SECTION: Section E; Column 1; The Arts/Cultural Desk; Pg. 7; BOOKS OF THE TIMES

LENGTH: 910 words

HEADLINE: Using American Power: Definite and Opposite Views

BYLINE: By RONALD D. ASMUS. 
Ronald D. Asmus was deputy assistant secretary of state for European affairs under President Bill Clinton and is now a senior trans-Atlantic fellow at the German Marshall Fund of the United States.

 BODY:

ALLIES
The U.S., Britain, Europe and the War in Iraq
By William Shawcross
261 pages. PublicAffairs. $20.

THE SORROWS OF EMPIRE
Militarism, Secrecy and the End of the Republic
By Chalmers Johnson
389 pages. Metropolitan Books/Henry Holt & Company. $25.
 There was a time when books about American foreign policy identified a problem, discussed policy options and marshaled evidence for the author's recommendation. It is a sign of our increasingly polarized times that books on American foreign policy today are increasingly about the United States itself: who we are, what we stand for and the purposes for which our might is rightly or wrongly used.
 The two books under review here are both polemics, although well-written and interesting ones. One makes the case for and the other against the use of American power. The arguments being made are noteworthy; so are the authors making them. ''Allies: The U.S., Britain, Europe and the War in Iraq'' is by William Shawcross, the British author viewed for years as a kind of model progressive. He is most famous for his excoriating attack on President Richard M. Nixon's and Henry A. Kissinger's pursuit of the war in Cambodia in ''Sideshow.''
 To the horror of previous admirers and the delight of conservatives, Mr. Shawcross appears to have undergone a midlife ideological conversion and emerged a defender of the Bush administration. The basic argument in ''Allies'' is that the current United States administration is run by honorable, intelligent men perfectly justified in concluding that Saddam Hussein posed an unacceptable risk and had to be removed from power. To accomplish this noble goal the United States had to take the lead, Britain had to follow, and the opposition of countries like France and Germany simply had to be swept aside. 
 To be sure, the administration has often been unfairly demonized in much of Europe. One can sympathize with Mr. Shawcross's effort to explain why President Bush and his national security team are not as evil or stupid as some critics claim and that Tony Blair was not a fool for following them. One also didn't have to be a neoconservative to conclude that containment was a moral and strategic error that was failing, that the West eventually had to confront Mr. Hussein, and that we were probably going to have to resort to force to solve the problem he and his regime posed.
 But in justifying the war, Mr. Shawcross at times comes across as a cheerleader glossing over the home team's shortcomings. The closest he comes to criticism is in noting Washington's less than perfect postwar planning for Iraq, a classic example of British understatement if there ever was one. The old William Shawcross who wrote ''Sideshow'' was less timid. The Iraq crisis produced one of the biggest diplomatic crackups in 50 years of trans-Atlantic relations. There is a great book to be written about what went wrong and why. One wishes Mr. Shawcross had used his formidable writing and investigative skills to write it.
 Chalmers Johnson is moving in the other direction. A distinguished scholar in Japanese and Asian studies, he documented in his recent book ''Blowback'' how American support of the anti-Soviet Islamic Afghan opposition boomeranged and helped contribute to the threat we face today from Al Qaeda and others. 
 In ''The Sorrows of Empire: Militarism, Secrecy and the End of the Republic,'' Mr. Johnson has unfortunately gone over to the dark side of conspiratorial explanations of American foreign policy. The United States, he argues, has been taken over by the forces of imperialism and militarism. Since Sept. 11 the United States has become an empire run by an out-of-control Pentagon, which is putting us on a path to probable collapse and ruin not unlike that of the Soviet Union. 
 Lest you think this book is your standard anti-Bush tirade, however, Mr. Johnson argues that President Bill Clinton was an even more effective imperialist because he understood the need to impose the national will on the world indirectly via globalization.
 Early in his book Mr. Johnson recalls visiting the American military base on Okinawa in Japan, a formative experience that convinced him of the pernicious nature of the American military and its overseas presence. It is a kind of metaphor for everything that is wrong with the Pentagon and also for an American foreign policy writ large that Mr. Johnson contends is bent on global domination. A look at the table of contents and chapters devoted to subjects like the roots of militarism, imperialism, the C.I.A.'s private armies and the spoils of war provides an overview of the arguments to come. At the end (and beginning) of the day American foreign policy is driven by profits and markets.
 This book is a cry from the heart of an intelligent person who fears the basic values of our republic are in danger. It conveys a sense of impending doom rooted in a belief that the United States has entered a perpetual state of war that will drain our economy and destroy our constitutional freedoms. 
 No doubt Mr. Johnson's motives in drawing public attention to these concerns are well intended. But there is also no doubt in my mind that his analysis is deeply flawed and his judgments at times grotesque. There is one problem with books that rely on conspiracy theory to explain American foreign policy. For anyone who has served in the government and seen how our foreign policy is made, they don't pass the reality test.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Former Chief Executive Of WorldCom Is Indicted
Federal prosecutors charged Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chief executive of the telecommunications giant WorldCom, with conspiring to commit the biggest accounting fraud in the history of American business.
 The company's former chief accounting officer, Scott D. Sullivan, who was also named in the indictment, pleaded guilty and said he would cooperate with prosecutors. Legal experts say Mr. Sullivan's decision to reach a plea agreement paved the way for the indictment of Mr. Ebbers and will be crucial to the chances of convicting him. [Page A1.]

Canada Lowers Benchmark Rate
The Bank of Canada lowered its benchmark interest rate for the second time this year, underlining the pressure on the biggest trading partners of the United States to counteract the dampening effect their strong currencies are having on their domestic economic growth. In announcing the cut in its overnight rate from 2.5 percent to 2.25 percent, the Canadian central bank said additional stimulus was needed ''to support aggregate demand.'' [World Business, Section W.]

Rise in Insurance Scams Found
Federal investigators said that they had found a sharp increase in health insurance scams by unlicensed companies.[A12.]

Major Stock Indicators Decline
Stocks declined yesterday. The S.&P. 500 lost 6.86 points, or 0.59 percent, to close at 1,149.10. The Nasdaq composite index shed 18.15 points, or 0.88 percent, to 2,039.65. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 86.66 points, or 0.81 percent, to 10,591.48. The dollar had its biggest rally against the euro in a year. [C9.]

Greenspan Discusses Currency
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said that neither the United States' huge trade deficit nor currency interventions by Japan and China pose a serious threat to the United States. [C4.]

Clothing Stores Set to Show Gains
After a disappointing holiday season, some of America's clothing merchants are getting ready to announce healthy sales numbers for February. [C5.]

FleetBoston to Pay $59.4 Million
FleetBoston Financial expects to pay $59.4 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges of trading abuses by its New York Stock Exchange market-making unit, according to a regulatory filing. [C5.]

Ex-Director Sells Big Board Seat
Kenneth G. Langone, the former director of the New York Stock Exchange most closely associated with its former chairman, Richard A. Grasso, sold his seat on the exchange for $1.5 million. [C2.]

Barclays Withdraw Hollinger Offer
David Barclay, left, and his brother Frederick formally withdrew their offer to acquire Hollinger Inc., but people close to them said that the billionaire brothers still wanted to buy the Telegraph newspapers of London, the jewels in Conrad M. Black's media empire. [World Business, Section W.]

Stay at Home for Coffee, Ads Urge
An advertising campaign will try to persuade consumers to stay at home for their coffee rather than visit coffeehouses like Starbucks. The campaign is pitching a new kind of coffee maker that brews a cup at a time in about a minute, using coffee in prepackaged packets called pods. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C7.]

Filling an Empty Space in Houston
Chevron's decision to buy an empty 40-story office tower built for the Enron Corporation is welcome news for downtown Houston. Commercial Real Estate. [C6.]

HEADLINE: Canada Lowers Its Key Interest Rate

BYLINE: By BERNARD SIMON

DATELINE: TORONTO, March 2 

 BODY:
The Bank of Canada lowered its benchmark interest rate on Tuesday for the second time this year, underlining the pressure on the biggest trading partners of the United States to counteract the dampening effect their strong currencies are having on their domestic economic growth. 
 In announcing the cut in its overnight rate from 2.5 percent to 2.25 percent, the Canadian central bank said additional stimulus was needed ''to support aggregate demand.'' 
 Much of the slowdown in Canada has been ascribed to shrinking exports, chiefly caused by a 22 percent appreciation of the Canadian dollar against the American dollar in 2003. Consumer spending has also slumped in recent months, with unexpectedly steep declines in motor vehicle sales. 
 Signaling similar concerns in Europe, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany, Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin of France and many business leaders have urged the European Central Bank to reduce its benchmark interest rate as a way of alleviating the pain to European exporters caused by the strong euro. The bank's governing council is scheduled to meet on Thursday to set the interest rate.
 In Japan, the impact of a strong yen on exports has also reinforced calls for more economic stimulus. The Bank of Japan raised the target range for commercial bank reserves in January as a way of increasing liquidity in the banking system and encouraging banks to lend more to companies and households. 
 ''We're getting some responses to the weakening of the dollar,'' said Stephen Gallagher, chief economist of Societe Generale's corporate and investment banking unit in New York. 
 Lower interest rates are intended to stimulate domestic demand through expanded borrowing. They also make a country less attractive to foreign capital, taking some pressure off an appreciating currency. A weakening currency makes exports more competitive, further bolstering economic growth.
 In the United States, the Federal Reserve has left the federal funds rate unchanged at 1 percent since the middle of last year. But Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, has suggested that an increase in interest rates has become more likely as the economic recovery gathers steam.
 Expectations of interest rate cuts and other types of monetary stimulus have put a brake on the climbing European, Japanese and Canadian currencies in recent weeks. 
 The euro was trading at about $1.22 on Tuesday, down from a record $1.29 on Feb. 18. The Japanese yen has also pulled back, while the Canadian dollar, which touched 79 cents earlier this year, was trading Tuesday below 75 cents. 
 The lowering of interest rates Tuesday in Canada underscores a widening divergence in the Canadian and American economies on a number of fronts. 
 ''Normally the Canadian and U.S. economies move in sync,'' Dale Orr, managing director at the Global Insight consultant firm in Toronto, wrote in a recent report. ''After all, our industrial structures and demand conditions are so similar. Over 80 percent of Canada's trade is with the U.S.''
 Now, Mr. Gallagher at Societe Generale said, ''the U.S. economy appears to be strengthening with very little employment growth, while Canada is experiencing the mirror image of that.''
 Canada's gross domestic product grew 1.7 percent last year, adjusted for inflation, half the pace in 2002 and well below the 3.1 percent growth rate posted by the United States.
 Mr. Orr projects an even wider gap this year, with the American economy expanding by 4.8 percent, but a growth rate of just 3 percent in Canada. 
 Canadian exports have contracted for three years. According to Shooshan Danagoulian, a Canadian specialist at the IDEAglobal consultant firm in New York, ''any fluctuations in the U.S. dollar hit the Canadian economy harder than any other.''
 Different approaches to fiscal policy in the two countries have reinforced their divergent growth performances. While the United States budget deficit has ballooned over the last two years, adding stimulus to the economy, the Canadian government has said it is committed to maintaining fiscal discipline in the form of a budget surplus. 
 The Canadian jobs market has so far been significantly stronger, partly because of rising employment in government-supported sectors like health care and education. But according to Mr. Orr, this is starting to change as the Canadian economy slows. 
 Ms. Danagoulian said that while the drop in interest rates might push the Canadian dollar lower over the next few months, ''we're expecting the Canadian dollar to return to its appreciating path in the second half of the year.''
 Citing robust demand for Canadian commodity exports, Ms. Danagoulian said the Canadian currency could reach 80 cents by the end of 2004.

HEADLINE: Catholic School Looks for Salvation (and an Affluent Angel or Two)

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
If they sell enough cookies and used knickknacks, cash in enough box tops and find an angel with deep pockets, Ava Milliner and her friends in East Harlem hope they keep their beloved Mount Carmel/Holy Rosary School from closing.
 So far they have about $5,000 in cash and pledges. That leaves them needing only $120,000 more. By Friday. At this rate, they'll need a legion of cherubs and a boxcar of cookies and box tops.
 Parents and teachers in the neighborhood are fuming over what they consider an impossible deadline set by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, which announced in late January that it was closing the school because of plummeting enrollment and rising deficits. After protests by parents and teachers who said they were blindsided by the decision, officials relented and gave the parents a little under a month to come up with the money and a long-term plan to save the school. 
 With Catholic schools relying on tuition to cover major costs like teacher salaries, declines in enrollment can have disastrous effects. 
 The schools -- which for decades have prided themselves on educating the children of immigrants and the poor -- have been hit hard since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, after a souring economy forced many families to either transfer children to public schools or move out of the city altogether. 
 Given that all the students at Mount Carmel/Holy Rosary qualify for free lunch and their parents have a hard enough time scraping together the $2,350 yearly tuition, coming up with $125,000 this week is about as likely as all of them winning the Lotto by week's end.
 ''It was an unrealistic deadline,'' said Ms. Milliner, who graduated from the school in 1984, and whose daughter, Averi Hill, is in third grade there. ''Three and a half weeks to raise $125,000 while the school was closed for Presidents' Week? How many people do you know would raise that kind of money in that short period of time? Had we known in September, we could have done it.'' 
 This has all happened several times before. Decades ago, when the neighborhood was largely Italian, the school was packed with children, until the demographic changes of the 1970's hit. 
 ''One summer the Italian families just up and left,'' said Penelope Preutzman, a second-grade teacher who started at Mount Carmel in 1968. ''I don't know exactly why. A lot of them had summer places in Long Beach and it got easier to move there.''
 It became so much harder to keep the school afloat that by the spring of 2001, the school was among six marked for closing by the archdiocese. Parents rallied and came up with a plan to increase enrollment and find patrons, ensuring the school's viability for three years. 
 Over the last year and a half, the school formed an active Parents Committee and won several more grants to add to its offerings both in the curriculum and after school. They have installed new computers, added a library teacher, set up an accelerated reading program and added an after-school performing arts program. All of these additions, parents and teachers said, should have helped them attract students.
 ''I knew there had been a three-year plan, but we thought everything was going to be fine,'' Ms. Preutzman said. ''I thought, well, we weathered the storm and we're O.K. Then they came in with this.''
 The news arrived with little warning.
 ''Nobody called the parents to say, 'We're short on money, we might close, enrollment is down too much.' Nobody said any of that,'' said Mary-Ann Perry, president of the Federation of Catholic Teachers, which represents the 11 lay teachers on the faculty. ''The letter sent to parents said they were going to close the school. You would think at least the people had a right to have some input.''
 Instead, the parents demanded that right in a testy meeting with archdiocesan officials, in which they said they wanted to cobble together a rescue plan. It was only later, several parents and teachers said, that they were told any plan had to include $125,000 to cover the deficit. They insist they have yet to see the books in order to determine just what the money would cover.
 Dr. Catherine Hickey, the archdiocese's secretary for education, insisted that the parents and teachers had not been blindsided. She faulted them for not having done much beyond relying on a single benefactor who provided about $100,000 a year.
 ''They depended on the benefactor to fill in the gaps,'' she said. ''Somehow the vision got lost.'' 
 Parents and teachers dispute that assertion, saying they had been successful in attracting grants to pay for new programs, including a $30,000 grant they received in January for a performing and visual arts program.
 They do not deny that the school suffered a devastating blow to its enrollment this year when it lost about 60 students over the summer. The question, they said, is how a system set up to educate the poor reconciles its mission with the bottom line.
 ''It's very sad when you have a school in an area where the parish cannot support it,'' said Patricia Gabriel, vice president of the teachers' union. ''These are the very kids which they should be supporting.''
 Dr. Hickey said there was more then enough room in the six other schools serving East Harlem to absorb the 180 students from Mount Carmel/Holy Rosary. In fact, that is part of the larger problem facing the schools in the region. Enrollment in the archdiocese's 238 elementary schools has dropped to 110,000 students, with a loss of 4,000 since 2001 and the economic downturn.
 ''Even though we lost 4,000 students, our costs have not gone down,'' Dr. Hickey said. ''It's not just an archdiocesan problem. The same thing is happening in Brooklyn, Newark and the country.''
 The economy has hit the people who send their children to the East Harlem school hard, Ms. Preutzman said. She knows of families who have removed their children to save money, while others have moved out of state to find better jobs and cheaper rents.
 Those who remain are hoping to raise what they can to save the school. A flea market last week raised $320. A bake sale pulled in another $226. Fliers tacked to the entrance urge parents to save box tops redeemable for cash. Their biggest single pledge, teachers and parents said, was $2,500 from the Rao family, whose famed Italian restaurant is a few blocks away.
 ''I taught one of the Rao children, but I didn't go ask,'' Ms. Preutzman said with a smile. ''We sent a nun to ask for the donation.''
 Ms. Milliner and other parents who have watched the neighborhood say they wonder if the impending closing might be driven by rising real estate prices in the area. 
 But Dr. Hickey said there was no plan to sell the building, and added that if the school closes, the building will house another archdiocesan program.
 That is small comfort to Ms. Milliner, who plans to ask the archdiocese for a deadline extension, something she would probably never have done during her days as a student. To underscore her stubborn hope, her committee has a full schedule of fund-raising events -- from school dances to a walk-athon -- planned through June.
 ''We're still working,'' she said. ''We're still making phone calls. We're still waiting for someone to answer our prayers.''

HEADLINE: Wall Street Executive To Purchase Devils

BYLINE: By DAVE CALDWELL

 BODY:
Jeffrey Vanderbeek, a New Jersey native, a hockey fan and a father of two young hockey players, said yesterday that he would be leaving the executive committee at Lehman Brothers to purchase and operate the Devils.
 Vanderbeek, 46, who has been with Lehman Brothers for 20 years, has been a minority owner of the Devils since Puck Holdings, an affiliate of the disbanding YankeeNets empire, bought the team in 2000.
 Vanderbeek said he had been a Devils season-ticket holder for about 15 years. Before he moved to Warren, N.J., Vanderbeek lived in South Orange, not far from the team training complex in West Orange. 
 ''It is tremendously exciting for me,'' Vanderbeek said in a telephone interview last night. ''To be able to move to a dream job, I consider myself extremely lucky.''
 He said he planned to resign from Lehman Brothers on June 15.
 No terms of the sale were disclosed, but the deal is expected to be approved by the National Hockey League Board of Governors within a week. Vanderbeek would become the managing partner and chairman of the Devils.
 Vanderbeek has been a proponent of a $300 million, 18,000-seat arena for the Devils in downtown Newark. The Devils, who have been reported to be nearly $70 million in debt, would move into the arena in 2007.
 ''The Devils need a new arena that can provide a game-day experience that is certainly equal to the best team in the National Hockey League and certainly equal to the product that is put on the ice,'' Vanderbeek said.
 Although they are the defending Stanley Cup champions, the Devils have failed to attract large crowds. They play their home games at Continental Arena, which is outdated and hard to reach by public transit. The Devils have sold out only 4 of 34 home games this season. Their average home attendance of 14,754 is only 2 percent higher than at a similar point last season.
 They sold out 3 of 41 home games last season, all in the last six weeks of the season. Two of the games were against the archrival Rangers.
 The Devils were among 19 N.H.L. clubs that lost money last season. According to a study commissioned by the N.H.L. and released last month by Arthur Levitt, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the 30 teams in the league lost a combined $273 million.
 Vanderbeek said a downtown arena in Newark would also help the revitalization of the city, in the same way that Oriole Park at Camden Yards helped downtown Baltimore and a ballpark and an arena helped downtown Cleveland.
 ''The experience they can have in Baltimore or Cleveland with the revitalization and redevelopment of the downtown areas is something that could happen in Newark,'' he said. ''The final pieces of those two cities were their arenas. I believe this would take downtown Newark to a whole new level.''
 Vanderbeek said he expected Lou Lamoriello, the Devils' president and general manager, to remain in his job. The Devils have won the Stanley Cup three times since 1995.
 ''I believe Lou is the best executive in professional sports,'' Vanderbeek said.
 Lamoriello, in a statement released by the Devils, said: ''Jeff is a quality individual who has a passion for the game of hockey. I am excited about the opportunity of working with him.''
 Vanderbeek's son, Rem, 16, is a sophomore hockey player at Seton Hall Prep, and his daughter, Rhiannon, 8, is a member of a boys mite hockey team. Vanderbeek said he did not have any specific duties as a Devils minority owner.
 Vanderbeek will take over a team that might not even play next season. A collective bargaining agreement between the owners and the players union expires Sept. 15, and few are optimistic that an agreement can be reached by then. A lockout is possible.
 According to Forbes magazine, the Devils were worth $145 million at the beginning of the 2003-4 season, down 9 percent from a year earlier.
 Ray Chambers and Lewis Katz head Puck Holdings, which bought the Devils for $175 million four years ago.

HEADLINE: A Vital Touchstone For High Schools

BYLINE: By Michael Winerip. 
E-mail: edmike@nytimes.com

DATELINE: SUDBURY, Mass. 

 BODY:
IN 1987, Will Fitzhugh started The Concord Review, a scholarly publication that printed the best high school history research papers in America. His intent was simple: to recognize students who produced high-quality research, to show teachers and students what could be done, and to thereby raise the standard for high school writing.
 On one level, he succeeded brilliantly. In 17 years, he has published 627 student papers in 57 issues of the quarterly, tackling some of history's most challenging questions. In a 6,235-word paper, Rachel Hines of Montgomery High in Rockville, Md., asked: Did Chaim Rumkowski, the Jewish leader of Poland's Lodz ghetto, do more good or harm by cooperating with the Nazis? Aaron Einbond of Hunter High in New York City explored to what extent John Maynard Keynes's economic ideas were truly revolutionary, and to what extent they were borrowed from others. 
 Jessica Leight of Cambridge Rindge and Latin in Massachusetts wanted to know why Anne Hutchinson suffered so much more at the hands of the Puritans than her brother-in-law, the Rev. John Wheelwright, when both attacked the leadership. Jennifer Shingleton of Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., questioned whether Abigail Adams really was a feminist, or was being taken out of 18th-century context by contemporary feminist historians.
 Britta Waller of Roosevelt High in Kent, Ohio, wrote about the Ferris wheel. ''Fascinating,'' Mr. Fitzhugh says. ''The guy who invented it died brokenhearted. I tell people, the topic doesn't matter, it's the quality that matters, so a kid learns the joy of scholarship. If you learn what it means to go in depth, you also realize when you're being superficial.''
 Some of America's best-known historians -- Arthur Schlesinger Jr., David McCullough, Shelby Foote -- have praised the Review. And the published students -- who often include their Review papers with their college applications -- have prospered. Seventy-four went on to Harvard, 57 to Yale, 30 to Princeton.
 And yet for much of the time, Mr. Fitzhugh has felt like a boatman on the Lewis and Clark expedition, paddling upstream on the Mississippi and making little headway. He fears the high school research paper is on the verge of extinction, shoved aside as students prepare for the five-paragraph essays now demanded on state tests, the SAT II and soon, the SAT. ''I'm convinced the majority of high school students graduate without reading a nonfiction book cover to cover,'' he says. Mr. Fitzhugh is offended that the National Endowment for the Humanities sponsors a $5,000 history essay contest with a 1,200-word limit. ''I have kids writing brilliant 5,000-word papers, and they're not eligible,'' he says. He is saddened by a letter from the chairman of the history department at Boston Latin, that city's premier high school. ''Over the past 10 years, history teachers have largely stopped assigning the traditional term papers,'' Walter Lambert, the chairman, wrote.
 While much of the education establishment crows about how standardized testing and the SAT writing sample are raising standards, Mr. Fitzhugh is not alone in seeing a dumbing down. Ken Fox, a college counselor at Ladue Horton Watkins High in St. Louis says that in test preparation courses, his students learn to write a generic five-paragraph essay that can be modified when they take the SAT. ''They're trained to write to formula,'' he says.
 He has urged students to submit papers to the Review, and Robert Levin did -- on the emancipation proclamation that John Fremont, a Union Army commander, issued in Missouri in 1861, two years before Lincoln's took effect. ''The big thing,'' says Robert, who wrote the paper on his own time, ''is I've been living here my whole life, interested in the Civil War, and never knew there was this whole huge deal of an emancipation proclamation in Missouri.''
 ''I loved breaking free from the writing formula they teach us,'' he says. ''I think that hampers your writing.''
 Mr. Fitzhugh has been called elitist, but Bruce Gans, a professor in the Chicago community college system who teaches a course on writing research papers, says students need to begin in high school. Mr. Gans says English 101 -- which requires an eight-page paper with eight sources -- is taught at Chicago's seven community colleges and has the highest class dropout rate in the system. ''Kids are terrified of that paper,'' Mr. Gans says. ''Will Fitzhugh is fighting by himself on this. I don't know how he does it.''
 BARELY. After graduating from Harvard in 1962, Mr. Fitzhugh held several jobs, including teaching high school history nearby for 10 years. That was when he came to believe that if you asked more of students, they would respond. He started the Review with his ''last $100,000,'' a family inheritance, plus the cashed-in value of his teaching pension. ''I'm stupid,'' he says, ''I thought people would subscribe.'' After 17 years, he has 1,100 subscribers and requires a $40 fee when a paper is submitted.
 Twice he has stopped publishing when he ran out of money. Most foundations -- 145 at last count -- have turned him down. His savior has been John Abele, co-founder of Boston Scientific, a medical equipment company that has provided $185,000 a year, enabling Mr. Fitzhugh to move the Review out of his house and to hire an assistant. They have started a National History Club in hopes of broadening its constituency.
 Each year, Mr. Fitzhugh offers four $3,000 awards, the Emerson prizes, for the best Review pieces. His dream is that the Emersons will do for high school history what the Intel research awards have done for science. But he never knows if he will be financed from year to year. ''John Abele has been wonderful,'' he says, ''but he had a stroke a few years ago. Thank God he recovered, but if something happens to him, we're history, so to speak.''
 Mr. Fitzhugh lives with his wife, Sophia, a retired teacher, in the same house they bought for $43,000 in 1971. His Review salary is $36,000 -- compared with $38,000 he made his last year teaching, 1988. ''I'll be 68 in August,'' he says. ''I'd like to retire after the 70th issue. What I need is to bring someone in before I fall over, but I don't have the money. The problem is, it's not a very prestigious job.''
