SECTION: Section A; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1; THE JOB PICTURE: THE OVERVIEW

LENGTH: 1314 words

HEADLINE: GROWTH IN JOBS IS STILL SLUGGISH DESPITE FORECAST

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
Job creation all but stalled in February, surprising Wall Street forecasters and giving Democrats economic ammunition to use against President Bush as he begins his re-election campaign.
 The economy added just 21,000 jobs last month, down sharply from January's increase and far below the gains that were common in the 1980's and 1990's. The unemployment rate held steady at 5.6 percent, the Labor Department reported yesterday, but mostly because many people have stopped looking for work since late last year, removing them from the government's official count of the jobless.
 ''This is a disappointment,'' said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist of the Prudential Equity Group. ''It shows very sluggish job creation in an economy which by almost all other measures is really doing very well.''
 With the slump in the job market nearing its third anniversary, economists said they were starting to wonder whether the relationship between economic growth and employment had changed in important ways. At no other point since World War II has the economy grown for such a long period without adding jobs at a healthy pace. 
 The failure of the economy to add more jobs so far presents Mr. Bush with a prickly political problem. Last year, he and his aides predicted that the three tax cuts passed since he took office would lift the economy out of its torpor and restore vigorous job growth.
 In October, Treasury Secretary John W. Snow estimated that 200,000 jobs a month would be created over the coming 12 months; since then, the economy has added just 52,000 jobs a month on average, and the administration has distanced itself from the forecasts.
 ''We're not satisfied,'' N. Gregory Mankiw, chairman of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, said in a telephone interview yesterday. ''The labor market has started to turn -- it just hasn't turned enough.'' 
 Mr. Mankiw said that raising taxes now, as Senator John Kerry, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, has proposed doing on families that make more than $200,000, would only weaken the economy further.
 Democrats responded that the Bush administration had tried stimulating the economy with little but tax cuts for high earners and that the strategy had not worked.
 ''You would think that after spending almost $3 trillion, you'd get more than 21,000 jobs,'' said Representative Rahm Emanuel, Democrat of Illinois. ''The president has not only a fiscal deficit, but a jobs deficit and a credibility deficit.''
 The report offered little good news. Weekly wages for most of the work force have risen less than 2 percent over the last year, roughly the rate of inflation. In February, manufacturers cut the number of workers on their payrolls for the 43rd consecutive month. The average length of unemployment increased to 20.3 weeks, its highest level since 1984.
 The best reason for hope, economists said, was last month's unusually harsh weather, which might have led households to delay some spending and companies to postpone projects, setting the stage for a surge in jobs in March.
 Interest rates on Treasury notes fell yesterday more sharply than they had since 2001, as investors concluded that the Federal Reserve was now all but certain to postpone any increase in its benchmark short-term interest rate until near the end of the year at the earliest. The dollar lost value relative to the euro, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose slightly, to 1,156.86. 
 Companies have remained remarkably reluctant to add workers even though the economy grew at an annual rate of 6.1 percent during the second half of last year -- the fastest pace in almost two decades -- and growth, most economists estimate, has continued at a pace not much slower since the year began.
 New technologies have helped companies produce more goods with fewer employees. The uneven growth of the last four years also seems to have made some executives wary that the good times will continue, while others have shifted some jobs to countries with lower wages. And the rising cost of health insurance has made executives think twice about adding workers, they say.
 ''This is a different cycle,'' said Joshua Shapiro, chief United States economist at Maria Fiorini Ramirez, an economic research firm in New York. ''To the extent that companies can squeeze another drop of blood out of their existing work force, they're doing it. Eventually you reach the point where there's no more blood to be given, but we haven't reached it yet.''
 When the economy grew at roughly its current rate during the 1980's and 1990's, monthly gains of more than 250,000 jobs were common. In February, messenger services, department stores, phone companies and food manufacturers all cut employment, according to the Labor Department, which adjusts its numbers to take into account normal seasonal variations. Restaurants, movie and music studios, and airlines created jobs, but overall employment in the private sector was flat. The government sector added 21,000 jobs, accounting for the entire net gain.
 In perhaps the clearest sign that the cold weather helped depress hiring, construction companies cut 24,000 positions.
 Since June, the Fed has kept its benchmark lending rate at 1 percent, a 50-year low, in an effort to encourage spending and shock the economy out of what has turned out to be -- while many degrees milder than the Depression -- the longest employment slump since the 1930's. After the release of yesterday's report, investors bet that the rate was likely to remain at 1 percent until at least the fall, based on the price of a futures contract tied to the benchmark rate.
 ''The pace of job growth remains well below anything approaching what the Fed would need to see to consider raising rates,'' Drew T. Matus, an economist at Lehman Brothers, wrote to clients. ''The clock is currently not even plugged in.''
 The Labor Department also revised its estimates for December and January, reporting that the economy gained 105,000 jobs during those two months, not the 118,000 it originally found. Teenagers, Latino workers and recent college graduates have borne the brunt of the labor market's problems in recent months.
 Despite the meager job growth, the unemployment rate remained at 5.6 percent last month, down from a peak of 6.3 percent in June. The decline is partly a mirage, many economists say, reflecting the large number of people who are not looking for work and thus not counted as unemployed. If the same portion of Americans had been in the labor force last month as in June, the jobless rate would have been 6.4 percent.
 But some White House officials and Congressional Republicans have also begun arguing that job growth is in fact better than the Labor Department's monthly survey of businesses shows. They note that a survey of households, which produces the jobless rate, shows greater job gains over the last three years.
 Unlike the business survey, the household survey includes self-employed people, whose numbers have grown over the last year. But the growth in their ranks is not large enough to explain the difference in the two surveys. 
 Both Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, and Kathleen P. Utgoff, the commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the agency that conducts the surveys, have said they consider the poll of businesses to be more accurate, although not perfect. It gathers information from 400,000 offices that employ 45 million workers, while the other survey asks questions of 60,000 households.
 Economists reiterated their projections yesterday that job growth would improve in the coming months, but some said they realized that they had now been saying the same thing for months. 
 ''There was a feeling out there that this was the month,'' Mr. Shapiro said. ''Now everyone will say it's just a matter of time, and we'll say the same thing. But we don't know how much time.''

HEADLINE: For a Little Off the Top, City Ends Free Jail Haircuts

BYLINE: By PAUL von ZIELBAUER

 BODY:
New York City has jacked up property taxes. It has cut fire companies. Now, city officials are zeroing in on what may just be a final frontier of fiscal prudence: inmate haircuts on Rikers Island. 
 Like it or not, the tonsorial free ride in city jails will soon be over. At a City Council hearing yesterday, the correction commissioner said the city would begin charging $2 per jailhouse cut (sans wash or blow-dry). 
 Tapping the inmate economy for revenue is just one way the Correction Department intends to raise more than $2 million to help balance its budget over the next two years. 
 In discussing the fee-for-haircut policy at the hearing, Commissioner Martin F. Horn showed a ready command of jailhouse fashion statistics. Councilwoman Yvette D. Clarke, who heads the Fire and Criminal Justice Services Committee, had barely finished asking Mr. Horn how many haircuts are given at Rikers Island each year when Mr. Horn delivered the answer with a brief smile: 172,000. 
 ''That is amazing that you know that,'' Ms. Clarke said.
 But in thinking outside the traditional budget box, Mr. Horn has ventured well beyond cashing in on his jailhouse hair salon, where the barbers are also inmates and tips, in whatever form, are strictly prohibited. Mr. Horn also announced plans to charge inmates more to use jail telephones. 
 The telephone access charge, currently 25 cents per call, will increase to 37 cents, Mr. Horn said, raising an estimated $500,000 in additional revenue for the department over the next two years. And to raise an additional $1 million, the department will institute a 2-cent-per-minute fee for calls that exceed inmates' daily allowance of free calls. Inmates are currently allowed one free six-minute phone call a day, and up to 20 minutes of phone time every five hours.
 Mr. Horn called the new phone charges ''philosophically appropriate'' because the city had been subsidizing the calls for years. 
 But inmate advocates said charging for haircuts and increasing fees to use telephones -- the only means for many inmates to communicate with the outside world -- was punitive and coldhearted. 
 John Boston, director of the Legal Aid Society's Prisoners' Rights Project, said a survey taken several years ago showed that half of the city's inmates had less than $5 available to them. ''Calling these measures 'philosophically appropriate' is the height of hypocrisy,'' Mr. Boston said in an e-mail message yesterday. ''Cheap and ugly is more like it.''

SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 3; THE JOB PICTURE: THE DATA

LENGTH: 674 words

HEADLINE: In the Latest Numbers, Economists See the Cold, Hard Truth About Jobs

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5 

 BODY:
For months, Bush administration officials and many Republicans have argued that the unemployment situation is better than the numbers suggest.
 But after Friday's extraordinarily weak jobs report, which showed a negligible increase of 21,000 jobs in February after months of rapid economic growth, economists both inside and outside the government have reached a similar conclusion: the numbers don't lie.
 Never before has the American economy seen such a prolonged divergence between economic growth and job creation. And rarely have the government's two main surveys on employment shown such conflicting results as they have in the last two years. 
 Top officials at the Federal Reserve Board, who have been fixated on the employment situation, have made it clear that they believe that jobs are being created more slowly than in any previous recovery, and well below the rate needed to bring down unemployment.
 As a result, Friday's Labor Department report is almost certain to persuade the central bank to delay any increase in interest rates for at least several more months, if not for the rest of the year.
 ''The numbers aren't lying,'' said Diane Swonk, chief economist at the Bank One Corporation. 
 Debate about the reliability of the government's jobs data has focused on two issues. The first is the enduring dissonance between evidence of a strong economy and a weak job market. Economists are increasingly becoming convinced that that puzzle can be explained by rapid increases in productivity. 
 The second issue is more technical. The findings of the two main employment surveys done by the Bureau of Labor Statistics have long shown a large discrepancy. 
 The payroll survey, which is based on responses from 400,000 companies, shows a loss of 2.2 million jobs since early 2001. The household survey, based on questions posed to about 50,000 households, shows an increase of about 500,000 jobs over the same period.
 Administration officials have argued that the household survey captures a happy new dimension to the job market: an increase in self-employed people working from home. 
 But Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told lawmakers last month that he is all but convinced that the household survey has been wrong and the payroll survey has been right.
 Economists at the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office have reached similar conclusions. Even the head of the Bureau of Labor Statistics agrees. ''The payroll survey is the best indicator of current job trends,'' Kathleen P. Utgoff, the bureau commissioner, said at a hearing of the Joint Economic Committee on Friday.
 Economists, including Ms. Utgoff, say the economy needs to add about 125,000 jobs a month just to keep up with growth in the number of workers. But the rate has been only half that high since last August, when the economy finally stopped losing jobs.
 More ominous, analysts say, is that hundreds of thousands of workers have stopped looking for jobs. About 392,000 workers dropped out of the work force last month, and the size of the labor force has contracted in six of the last eight months.
 In most recoveries, exactly the opposite occurs. As they become more optimistic, people who had been too discouraged to look for work jump back into the work force. That phenomenon often leads to a misleading rise in the unemployment rate, because the number of people classified as workers jumps faster than the number of new jobs.
 During this recovery, the number of discouraged workers has risen so markedly that the official unemployment rate has edged down since last summer. Since March 2001, the share of the population that is officially in the work force has declined to 65.9 percent from 67.1 percent. 
 Jared Bernstein, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a left-of-center research group here, estimated that unemployment would be 7.3 percent today, rather than the official level of 5.6 percent, if the rate of work force participation was as high today as it was three years ago.

HEADLINE: Companies Hold Off on Hiring Until Demand Rises

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
By almost every measure, the economy has been expanding at a healthy pace for six months. But the nation's employers remain stubbornly reluctant to add jobs in the United States.
 Outsourcing abroad, particularly the shifting of work to China and India, so much in the news, is one reason hiring at home has been sparse. Another is rising productivity, squeezing more work from existing staff and other efficiencies. 
 But these are only two aspects of a much broader syndrome that might be described as just-in-time hiring. Instead of optimistically adding workers in anticipation of demand, as in the past, the new mind-set is to hold off until the demand for a company's product or service is so great that an employer has no choice but to hire, and then add as few people as possible.
 ''Companies do not want to take on new workers unless they absolutely have to, and they do not have to yet,'' said Nigel Gault, chief domestic economist at Global Insight, a forecasting and data gathering concern.
 Despite strong economic growth since last summer, the current recovery started out very slowly and that helps to explain the lack of hiring. The economy has expanded at an average annual rate of only 3.6 percent since the recession ended in the fourth quarter of 2001. By comparison, the growth rate averaged 5.7 percent in the opening two years of the previous eight recoveries. But even in the early 1990's, when job growth was also slow to recover, hiring was more robust at this stage of the expansion than it is now.
 The reluctance to hire is evident at Parker Hannifin, a manufacturer of industrial controls based in Cleveland. Orders finally picked up in the late fall, and now they are running a robust 20 percent ahead of last year.
 If that trend continues, Parker Hannifin will begin to add workers in the summer, but not regular employees. Most will come from Manpower and similar temporary help agencies, said Tim Pistell, the chief financial officer. In the meantime, Parker Hannifin has stopped the layoffs and attrition that eliminated 8,000 employees over the last three years. Employees who resign or retire are finally being replaced.
 ''I would say we cannot go much more than another quarter without adding people, if orders hold up,'' Mr. Pistell said. ''But we will hire cautiously. We've had a couple of head fakes in this recovery, when we thought the hard times were over for us and they weren't.''
 Temporary workers, in fact, are the fastest-growing segment of the work force, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Since August, when employers finally began to add more jobs than they eliminated, temporary workers have led the parade. Temporary help jobs increased by 112,000 in this period, bringing the total to 2.37 million as of last month. That is up from virtually zero in the late 1970's.
 Temporary workers, and their first cousins, contract workers, play a crucial role in a growing corporate practice. Companies increasingly divide their work forces into a core group of permanent, well-paid employees surrounded by less-skilled, lower-wage workers who can be brought in and sent away as demand fluctuates.
 ''The goal of companies is not to hire,'' said Larry Geiger, a vice president of the American Management Association who supervises the association's surveys of corporate executives.
 The executives are focused instead on fattening profits to push up stock prices and recover ground lost in the market plunge that started in 2000, he said. Since they cannot raise profits by raising prices in a period of low inflation, they are doing it by suppressing labor costs -- getting more output from the existing work force. And the profit share of corporate income has risen in recent quarters at the expense of labor's share, the Bureau of Economic Analysis reports.
 Still, companies are announcing their intentions to hire more frequently now. In an American Management Association survey of 230 executives last December, 48 percent said they would add workers this year, up from 38 percent in the poll a year earlier. Other organizations have reported similar poll results in recent weeks, encouraging optimism that February would finally be a breakthrough month, producing more than 100,000 new jobs rather than the meager 21,000 reported yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
 Mr. Geiger said he was not surprised. ''What these executives do is budget for an increase in employment, and their answers reflect the budgeted funds,'' he said. ''But if revenue projections are not met, they cancel the budgeted hiring, and that is happening frequently.'' 
 Other shifts also damp hiring; some are intended while others are beyond any individual company's control. Hiring came back sooner in earlier recoveries because employers stepped up production not only to fill current orders but to build inventories, warehousing extra merchandise to meet surges in demand. 
 That no longer happens, particularly in manufacturing, which has been shedding jobs for 43 consecutive months while many other sectors are gradually beginning to add jobs. Parker Hannifin, for example, adjusts production almost daily to match the previous day's sales. As a result of this tactic, the Commerce Department's inventory-to-sales ratio, a measure of the number of months needed to sell off existing inventories, has fallen to less than 1.4 months from nearly 1.6 months in the early 1990's. 
 In past recoveries, companies stepped up their hiring in response to two other dynamics. As the economy improved, they invested in new machinery, computers and other capital goods to meet rising demand. The capital goods manufacturers in turn added workers, who then spent their salaries on goods and services, and employment rose in these sectors, too. 
 The same dynamic is happening now, but a growing portion of the spending is going abroad, creating jobs in other countries rather than the United States. That is because the value of imported capital goods, measured as a percentage of total expenditures, excluding cars and trucks, rose to just under 40 percent last year from just over 30 percent in 1990 and 15 percent in 1980. Similarly, spending on imported consumer goods and services as a percentage of total outlays stands at 12 percent today, up from 7 percent in 1990 and 4 percent in 1980.
 ''What we are looking at now is a more extreme version of the early 1990's, when we also experienced a jobless recovery but not as severe as this one,'' said Edward McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. ''We have no way of knowing when hiring will pick up; we don't have models for what is happening now.''

HEADLINE: Pataki in Tentative Deal With Largest Union

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
The Pataki administration and the state's largest public employees union said yesterday that they had agreed on a tentative contract that would raise the salaries of 70,000 state workers by what union officials said was 11 percent over the next four years.
 The tentative agreement with the union, the Civil Service Employees Association, which has been without a contract since April, would cost the state $352 million over the course of the contract, a state official said. The governor and the State Legislature are negotiating a plan to close a $5.1 billion shortfall in next year's budget. 
 The proposed settlement would give workers an $800 one-time payment upon ratifying the contract, followed by raises of between 2.5 percent and 3 percent a year over the next three years. On the last day of the contract in March 2007, workers would get an $800 increase on their base salary. 
 The union said workers making $26,475 now would see their salaries grow to $29,520 by the end of the contract. 
 The settlement would require workers to pay higher co-payments for doctors' visits, officials said. The contract would cover clerical workers, mental health workers and members of road crews, among other state employees. 
 The union's contract is traditionally a bellwether that helps set the terms of other state contracts. 
 Gov. George E. Pataki described the pact in a statement as a ''fair contract.'' Daniel F. Donohue, the union president, said in a statement that the agreement ''demonstrates the state's commitment to our members in the short and long term.''
 The contract will be watched closely by New York City unions, which have been battling Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's insistence that any wage increases they get be paid for by higher productivity or other savings included in their contracts. 
 Randi Weingarten, the chairwoman of the Municipal Labor Committee, which coordinates bargaining for the city's unions, said she hoped the mayor would take note that the state found a way to raise its employees' pay even though it was facing a budget gap and an economy that is weaker than the city's.

HEADLINE: Markets Hold as Low-Interest Hopes Counter Jobs Report

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Bond prices rose, yields plunged and the dollar fell yesterday in the wake of a surprisingly weak February jobs report, suggesting that any interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve will not come as soon as had been predicted. The stock market, where slow job creation is a negative and low interest rates a positive, was little changed.
 The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note fell to 3.85 percent, its lowest since July. If the yield remains in this area, mortgage rates, which are already low, could decline further next week. 
 The dollar, which had reached a 2004 high Thursday, declined 1.5 percent against the euro. But the dollar actually rose against the Japanese yen after the Bank of Japan, according to analysts, intervened in the foreign exchange market to prevent the yen from rising against the dollar.
 The intervention is aimed at keeping Japan's export business competitive abroad by maintaining as weak a yen as possible against the dollar and other currencies. Some analysts estimated that the Bank of Japan, which spent more than 20 trillion yen (around $185 billion) last year to keep the dollar stronger and the yen weaker, bought as much as $10 billion with yen yesterday. 
 Interest rates and the dollar fell, analysts said, because the 21,000 new jobs created in February were so far below expectations of about 130,000 that an interest rate increase expected from the Federal Reserve as early as this summer is now not expected until at least the end of the year.
 ''The market has finally pushed the Fed out of this year,'' said James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at J.P. Morgan, referring to expectations for a Fed rate increase. 
 ''We know rates are too low for the long haul,'' he added. But with job creation so slow, he added, ''we are not in the long haul now.'' 
 While some economists worry that slow job growth will impede recovery, the drop in interest rates, if it lasts, could provide a little extra lift for the housing and mortgage refinancing businesses and provide consumers who refinance more cash to spend.
 To the surprise of many analysts, mortgage rates are falling this year instead of rising. The national 30-year mortgage was at 5.59 percent this week, down from 5.81 percent at the end of last year and not far above the 45-year low of 5.21 percent last June, according to Freddie Mac.
 Frank A. Nothaft, Freddie Mac's chief economist, said that some consumers should have seen lower mortgage rates as soon as yesterday and that Freddie Mac's national average rate would be ''much lower'' next week if yesterday's decline in Treasury yields holds.
 In the Treasury market, the price of the 10-year note increased 111/32, to 1017/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 3.85 percent, from 4.02 percent on Thursday.
 The dollar fell as the euro rose to a value of $1.2378, from $1.2188 on Thursday. While the fall was big, the dollar had risen 2.5 percent against the euro through Thursday of this week on the expectation that the jobs report would be strong and that the Fed would raise interest rates sooner than expected. Against the yen, the dollar was at 112.02, up from 111.06 Thursday.
 ''Japan's economic policy of currency manipulation has gone from slowing the appreciation of the yen to stabilizing the yen to its current form of weakening the yen,'' David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, wrote in his commentary yesterday. 
 William E. Rhodes, chief investment strategist at Rhodes Analytics, said that initially the jobs report seemed bad for the stock market. But that worry was then offset by the belief that any Fed rate increase would be delayed.
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 7.55 points, or 0.1 percent, to 10,595.55, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 1.99 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,156.86. The Nasdaq composite index fell 7.48 points, or 0.4 percent, to 2,047.63.

HEADLINE: Sun Microsystems Debt Cut to 'Junk'

BYLINE: By LAURIE J. FLYNN

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 5 

 BODY:
After a period of small but steady improvement, shares of Sun Microsystems sank on Friday after Standard & Poor's announced that it had cut Sun's corporate credit rating to junk status. 
 The company's shares fell 36 cents, or 7 percent, on the news to close at $4.80. 
 The credit rating company cited continuing financial losses and fierce competition in the market for computer network servers. Sun, based in Mountain View, Calif., has posted 11 consecutive quarters of declining revenue since 2001. 
 Sun has about $1.3 billion of senior unsecured notes, and about $5 billion of cash and marketable securities, Standard & Poor's said. It cut Sun's corporate credit rating to BB+, its highest junk rating, from BBB. The outlook is stable.
 ''The downgrade reflects weak and inconsistent profitability, and the expectation that Sun will be challenged to profitably expand its market presence,'' said Martha Toll-Reed, Standard & Poor's credit analyst. 
 She said she did not expect the company's profitability to return to historical levels in the near-to-immediate future.
 Friday's move by the credit agency is a big blow to Sun's recent efforts to turn its fortunes around. During the second quarter of fiscal 2004, the company's revenues topped analysts' projections, rising 13.9 percent over the first quarter, the highest growth rate from a first quarter to a second since 1998. Sun's stock closed Thursday at $5.16 after starting off the year at $4.49
 Ms. Toll-Reed said the company continued to face enormous hurdles in the server market where it competes with I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard, as well as with Dell Computer at the low end of the market. Dell has in recent years moved aggressively into that market, selling less-expensive servers based on industry standard technologies like Linux and Microsoft Windows. By contrast, Sun continues to rely on selling more-expensive servers, based on its own proprietary version of Unix. 
 ''The biggest competitors are clearly I.B.M. and H.P., but not to be discounted is the low-end impact of a Dell Computer, who's got a very effective cost model,'' Ms. Toll-Reed said. ''You can't do the same things with a Dell server and a Sun high-end server, but the cost factor is not to be underestimated.''
 Brent Bracelin, an analyst with Pacific Crest Securities, said he was surprised at the timing of the downgrade, because Sun's financial position has improved in recent months. ''We're projecting them to show their first year-over-year revenue growth in the March quarter,'' Mr. Bracelin said. ''Sun certainly has several challenges ahead of it, but we're at the start of things getting better. They're in a better position now than they were last year at this time.''
 Mr. Bracelin said Sun stands to gain from what appears to be more spending in corporate technology centers, along with the improving economy.
 But in Ms. Toll-Reed's view, Sun's commitment to maintaining substantial investments in research and development -- which may pay off in innovative products -- also takes a toll on the company's bottom line.
 Sun executives defended the company's financial position, as well its strategy.
 ''Sun has a strong financial foundation of $5.161 billion in cash and marketable securities, which is over three times our outstanding debt,'' said Jeff Boldt, director of investor relations for Sun. ''With this strong financial foundation, a broad range of products, technologies and solutions, and a global base of customers and partners, Sun is well positioned to achieve its goals.''

HEADLINE: Outsourcing Is Becoming A Harder Sell in the U.S.

BYLINE: By EDUARDO PORTER; Jennifer Bayot contributed reporting for this article.

 BODY:
Globalization is having a bad year. Unions do not like it. Politicians on the campaign trail rail against it. As each monthly employment report confirms the anemic pace of job creation -- yesterday's report was especially grim -- more members of Congress talk about obstructing it. 
 Now, even some practitioners are speaking out against globalization. 
 ''I really hate it,'' said Al Lubrano, president of Technical Materials Inc., a Lincoln, R.I., manufacturer of specialty metal parts for computers, telecommunications equipment and other applications. ''I think we're really selling out our manufacturing community down the river.'' 
 But like many other American business executives, Mr. Lubrano has had to join the trend: Next year Technical Materials plans to open its first operation in China.
 The gap between the stated ideal and the business reality is also evident with Angelo R. Mozilo, the chairman of Countrywide Financial, one of the largest mortgage lenders, who was quoted in October in the trade publication National Mortgage News as saying, ''I feel it is Countrywide's responsibility to create jobs in the U.S., not outside the U.S.'' 
 By this year, however, Mr. Mozilo was describing how Countrywide had leased 40,000 square feet of office space in Bombay and planned to create 250 customer service and support jobs there over the next two years. (Mr. Mozilo declined to be interviewed for this article.)
 The business community's dissonant attitudes toward global outsourcing -- hiring out work overseas -- are evident in the results of a survey released yesterday by the business consultant McKinsey & Company. The survey of 7,300 senior executives from companies around the world found that roughly four out of five executives said that outsourcing was good for the global economy, an approval ratio that was virtually the same in Europe, Asia and the United States and is in keeping with the views of many economists. 
 But when the executives were asked about the effects of outsourcing on their own businesses, the executive consensus broke down. In Europe, 70 percent of executives said outsourcing was good for business. So did 86 percent of Chinese executives and 97 percent of those in India. 
 Yet in the United States, headquarters to many of the most aggressive and successful globalizing companies, the fraction of executives that said outsourcing was either very positive or somewhat positive for their company dropped to 58 percent.
 Some of this ambivalence may reflect the growing political hostility in this country against outsourcing, which has come to a boil in the face of lackluster job creation despite robust economic growth. 
 On the presidential campaign stump, Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, regularly condemns the ''Benedict Arnold'' companies that send jobs overseas. Senate Democrats are backing a bill that would require executives to provide at least 90 days' notice if they plan to lay off more than 14 workers to move their functions overseas. On Thursday, the Senate passed by a large margin a measure that would put new restrictions on government contractors' shifting jobs overseas. 
 Foreign direct investment by American corporations has averaged roughly $125 billion annually over the last 10 years. Though much of this was devoted to serve foreign markets, a growing portion has sought to reap the benefits of cheap labor and resources to make products and services for sale back home.
 Now, cheap communications technology has opened vast new spaces to outsourcing, including white-collar service functions like data processing and software design. A study by the McKinsey Global Institute, McKinsey's internal research center, estimated that in 2002, multinationals moved nearly $35 billion of such spending offshore. And the study predicted that as more companies took advantage of cheap global communications, the ''offshoring'' of jobs would grow by 30 to 40 percent annually through 2008.
 ''Outsourcing has so far been modest compared to what's to come,'' said Lael Brainard of the Brookings Institution in Washington. Brian Keane, chief executive of Keane Inc., a Boston-based company that handles back-office operations for companies, said executives increasingly were concluding that they had no alternative to sending jobs overseas, despite the growing political heat.
 ''You almost can't afford not to,'' Mr. Keane said. ''That's the bottom line.'' Otherwise, he added, competitors will end up ''eating your lunch.''
 Smaller companies in the United States that serve big globalizing behemoths are probably the most anxious of them all. Ask Mr. Lubrano. Though Technical Materials is a unit of a larger public company -- Brush Engineered Materials of Cleveland -- it fits into the category of small company at the mercy of big multinationals. And Mr. Lubrano feels that he is globalizing under duress.
 ''Our customers' customers have moved to China,'' he said. ''This goes down the ladder, one rung at a time.'' 
 For instance, Technical Materials used to supply parts to suppliers of Motorola, the big cellphone maker, he said. But when Motorola moved production capacity to China, it took many of those suppliers with it, costing Mr. Lubrano business. Now another customer is migrating to China. This time Technical Materials will go, too. 
 ''On and on it goes,'' Mr. Lubrano said. ''We've got to stop it. Manufacturers in this country can't stop that without our government taking action.''

HEADLINE: Job Data Provides Ammunition for Two Sides in Presidential Race

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5 

 BODY:
The latest unemployment statistics escalated the political war over the economy on Friday, with Democrats asserting that lackluster job growth underscored the failures of the Bush administration's economic policy while Republicans countered that a tax-raising Democratic president would only make it worse.
 On Capitol Hill and on the campaign trail, Democrats ridiculed the administration for falling far short of its promises to restore a healthy job market. Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, told a cheering rally of workers protesting the migration of jobs overseas: ''President Bush has said the economy is growing, that there are jobs out there. But you know, it's a long commute to China to get those jobs.'' 
 Senator John Kerry, the all-but-official Democratic nominee, said that Mr. Bush had ''overpromised and underdelivered,'' saying that at the current rate of job growth, it would take almost a decade to replace the more than two million jobs lost under this administration. 
 Later, at a rally in New Orleans, Mr. Kerry attacked the administration's economic policies, responding to Vice President Dick Cheney's claim that Democratic proposals for higher taxes on the rich would harm the economy.
 ''Dick Cheney went on TV and said if we had John Kerry's tax policies, we wouldn't have had the job growth we've had in the country right now,'' Mr. Kerry told the crowd. ''I came here to say today, 'You're darn right, Mr. Vice President. We'd have had real job growth; Americans would be working.'''
 Republicans had clearly hoped for a much better performance in February than the creation of only 21,000 jobs but still went on the offensive. ''President Bush has provided steady leadership that has put us on the road to economic recovery,'' said Terry Holt, spokesman for the Bush campaign. ''John Kerry's 20-year record of supporting higher taxes for businesses and families would derail America's economic recovery.''
 The Bush campaign itemized what it asserted was a long history of Kerry votes for higher taxes, ''more regulation and red tape,'' and against legislation that would limit ''frivolous lawsuits'' and ''lower health care costs.''
 Throughout the day, Bush officials argued that Mr. Kerry would represent a risky shift in direction on the economy, just as they previously argued he would be on national security. This reflected the overarching theme of the Bush re-election effort, which formally kicked into gear this week with a major advertising campaign.
 Still, Glen Bolger, whose firm is part of the Bush campaign's polling team, acknowledged, ''Clearly, you'd like to see the job growth a little more robust than 21,000.'' But he added, ''The president is realistic when he says, 'We're not done yet, there's lots more to do.'''
 John Feehery, spokesman for the House speaker, J. Dennis Hastert, said: ''No one should be happy about these numbers. It just shows you there is a changing economy out there. But Democrats are talking about economic isolationism, and that's not going to create any more jobs.''
 In fact, the nation's trade agreements and their effect on employment emerged as one of the most powerful issues during the Democratic nominating season, and the new job figures only fed those fires. At the rally on Capitol Hill on Friday, workers held signs declaring, ''Outsource Bush'' and ''Stop Exporting American Jobs.'' They heard from a worker at an Electrolux refrigerator plan in Michigan that is scheduled to close and transfer much of its work to Mexico.
 ''It's like a stomachache that will not go away,'' said the worker, Dave Doolittle.
 Senator Byron Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, was one of several Democrats who scoffed at Mr. Bush for promoting the possibility this week that lots of companies might add two or three workers each as a result of his tax policies. ''We've lost three million jobs since he's been in office!'' Mr. Dorgan declared.
 Stephanie Cutter, spokeswoman for the Kerry campaign, said on Friday that the Bush campaign was ''having a hard time conducting the campaign on the real issues Americans face -- like good schools, a good economy, good health care and a sound and safe future, so they're going to cultural issues like gay marriage'' and attacks on Mr. Kerry. 
 Democrats and their allies, in fact, seem increasingly emboldened on the economy. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. now has a banner, hanging a block away on the side of its headquarters building facing the White House, that declares, ''Show Us the Jobs!''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Workers rallying on Capitol Hill yesterday. The Labor Department reported that the U.S. economy gained 21,000 jobs last month. (Photo by European Pressphoto Agency)

HEADLINE: The Secret Of Our Sauce

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: BANGALORE, India 

 BODY:
Yamini Narayanan is an Indian-born 35-year-old with a Ph.D. in economics from the University of Oklahoma. After graduation, she worked for a U.S. computer company in Virginia and recently moved back to Bangalore with her husband to be closer to family. When I asked her how she felt about the outsourcing of jobs from her adopted country, America, to her native country, India, she responded with a revealing story:
 ''I just read about a guy in America who lost his job to India and he made a T-shirt that said, 'I lost my job to India and all I got was this [lousy] T-shirt.' And he made all kinds of money.'' Only in America, she said, shaking her head, would someone figure out how to profit from his own unemployment. And that, she insisted, was the reason America need not fear outsourcing to India: America is so much more innovative a place than any other country. 
 There is a reason the ''next big thing'' almost always comes out of America, said Mrs. Narayanan. When she and her husband came back to live in Bangalore and enrolled their son in a good private school, he found himself totally stifled because of the emphasis on rote learning -- rather than the independent thinking he was exposed to in his U.S. school. They had to take him out and look for another, more avant-garde private school. ''America allows you to explore your mind,'' she said. The whole concept of outsourcing was actually invented in America, added her husband, Sean, because no one else figured it out.
 The Narayanans are worth listening to at this time of rising insecurity over white-collar job losses to India. America is the greatest engine of innovation that has ever existed, and it can't be duplicated anytime soon, because it is the product of a multitude of factors: extreme freedom of thought, an emphasis on independent thinking, a steady immigration of new minds, a risk-taking culture with no stigma attached to trying and failing, a noncorrupt bureaucracy, and financial markets and a venture capital system that are unrivaled at taking new ideas and turning them into global products.
 ''You have this whole ecosystem [that constitutes] a unique crucible for innovation,'' said Nandan Nilekani, the C.E.O. of Infosys, India's I.B.M. ''I was in Europe the other day and they were commiserating about the 400,000 [European] knowledge workers who have gone to live in the U.S. because of the innovative environment there. The whole process where people get an idea and put together a team, raise the capital, create a product and mainstream it -- that can only be done in the U.S. It can't be done sitting in India. The Indian part of the equation [is to help] these innovative [U.S.] companies bring their products to the market quicker, cheaper and better, which increases the innovative cycle there. It is a complimentarity we need to enhance.''
 That is so right. As Robert Hof, a tech writer for Business Week, noted, U.S. tech workers ''must keep creating leading edge technologies that make their companies more productive -- especially innovations that spark entirely new markets.'' The same tech innovations that produced outsourcing, he noted, also produced eBay, Amazon.com, Google and thousands of new jobs along with them.
 This is America's real edge. Sure Bangalore has a lot of engineering schools, but the local government is rife with corruption; half the city has no sidewalks; there are constant electricity blackouts; the rivers are choked with pollution; the public school system is dysfunctional; beggars dart in and out of the traffic, which is in constant gridlock; and the whole infrastructure is falling apart. The big high-tech firms here reside on beautiful, walled campuses, because they maintain their own water, electricity and communications systems. They thrive by defying their political-economic environment, not by emerging from it.
 What would Indian techies give for just one day of America's rule of law; its dependable, regulated financial markets; its efficient, noncorrupt bureaucracy; and its best public schools and universities? They'd give a lot.
 These institutions, which nurture innovation, are our real crown jewels that must be protected -- not the 1 percent of jobs that might be outsourced. But it is precisely these crown jewels that can be squandered if we become lazy, or engage in mindless protectionism, or persist in radical tax cutting that can only erode the strength and quality of our government and educational institutions.
 Our competitors know the secret of our sauce. But do we?

HEADLINE: Facing New Crisis, Haiti Again Relies on U.S. Military to Keep Order

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER and LYDIA POLGREEN; Reporting for this article was contributed by Rachel L. Swarns, Eric Schmitt and Christopher Marquis in Washington, Warren Hoge at the United Nations and William K. Rashbaum in New York.

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 6 

 BODY:
Jean Rodrigue peered through the green gates of the palace wall, struggling to take in the sight of a dozen or more United States marines in armored vehicles on the lawn of the National Palace that President Jean-Bertrand Aristide had fled. 
 A decade ago, Mr. Rodrigue had wept for joy when Mr. Aristide, Haiti's first democratically elected president, returned with the help of the American military. Now he is gone, and American troops are trying to mop up the mess he left behind.
 ''There was so much hope then,'' Mr. Rodrigue, a 40-year-old biology teacher, said, staring vacantly at the marines from underneath a wide-brimmed straw hat. ''We all believed in Aristide and we believed the world would help us.'' 
 Now the United States military is back in Haiti for the third time in 90 years. It says its mission will last 90 days. On June 1, the United States plans to hand off to an international force under the United Nations. Planning for that force has barely begun, and Haiti's 15 neighbors in the Caribbean, furious at Mr. Aristide's ouster under American pressure, say they want no part of it. 
 Trying to put Haiti back together again may well require more soldiers, more time and more money than the last American military deployment, in 1994, to build lasting institutions, like the police, courts and schools. The $3 billion spent by the United States during those years has washed away like the soil on Haiti's denuded hills. 
 Many of the armed rebels who rose up in Haiti this past month are veterans of the junta that overthrew Mr. Aristide in 1991. They have not put down their arms as they have promised. United States Special Forces have flown to the rebels' strongholds outside Port-au-Prince to try to persuade them to do so.
 United States military officers are working with senior members of Haiti's police force trying to reform a rabble of demoralized and poorly trained officers, who have been unable to bring order to a deeply divided country of heavily armed citizens with grievances and long memories. United States officials said the new police chief would be Leon Charles, 38, who has worked with them before as a Haitian Coast Guard commander. 
 The Haitian government, torn between rival elites, has traditionally ignored the needs of Haiti's poor, who saw in Mr. Aristide a champion of their interests. Though a ''council of elders'' was formed Friday to try to select nominees for a provisional government, political discourse here is still often carried out at gunpoint.
 When the last American-led military mission in Haiti ended in 1996, it left behind a nation that slowly fell apart again, dissolving into the monthlong armed rebellion that led Mr. Aristide to exile. Haitians hope for better this time, but history has taught them many cruel lessons. 
 Before the Americans left, Mr. Aristide decided to send home the soldiers of the Haitian Army with their guns but no jobs or compensation. As a result, many soldiers joined the rebels to seek his ouster, and the rebels now want to bring back the much feared Haitian Army. 
 A three-month occupation would be the shortest dalliance in a long and inauspicious American history of military engagement with Haiti. The first American occupation lasted two decades, from 1915 to 1934. The second, starting in 1994, involved 20,000 American-led troops.
 This time around, the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, says, any peacekeeping force will have to be a long-term mission. An in-and-out operation may have little effect on a nation so scarred, where legitimate authority is shaky after what some Haitians see as an American-backed coup. 
 The United States ''didn't think about the endgame when they had Aristide leave,'' said Arturo Valenzuela, a former National Security Council officer for Latin America. ''They thought the problem was the bad leader, just like in Iraq, and that the departure of the bad leader would have a good outcome. Political order has to be established with legitimate force. Only the U.N. can do that.''
 A United Nations Security Council resolution passed last Sunday only approved the dispatch of troops by member countries. About 1,900 have arrived -- 1,200 Americans, 500 French, 130 Chileans and 60 Canadians. Canada pledged 390 more and Brazil has promised troops. The improvised American-led effort may grow to 5,000 soldiers, including about 2,000 marines, this month.
 But there is no visible recruitment yet for a United Nations force. ''The U.N. is not in the business of recruiting,'' said Fred Eckhard, Mr. Annan's spokesman. ''If you want that, speak to the United States and its friends.'' 
 Mr. Annan, under the resolution, has 25 days left to create a peacekeeping force. Until then, the United States is in charge. But as in Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans, it may prove easier for American troops to land in Haiti than to leave. 
 Raymond W. Kelly, now the New York police commissioner, strove to create a working force for law and order in Haiti a decade ago. But the national police dwindled to a force of less than 3,000, became dissolute and corrupt, and barely exists today. 
 To re-establish order, ''clearly you need more resources than were ever talked about there'' in the past, Mr. Kelly said. ''You'd be talking roughly 20,000 police in Haiti.'' 
 Training and equipping a force that size could take years.
 The question of the Haitian Army also overshadows the country's future. Mr. Aristide dissolved it in 1995; the armed rebels have announced its resurrection. The army was created by the American military after it occupied the country and imposed martial law in 1915. 
 Mary A. Renda, author of ''Taking Haiti,'' an award-winning history of the American occupation, said the Marines created ''a military that was intended to be used against the Haitian people.'' 
 The government is riven by factions. Beyond the rebels, whom the United States has told to lay down their arms, there remain loyal Aristide ministers and supporters, and the political opposition led by Haiti's elites.
 Many Aristide loyalists are still hiding from rebel death threats, and many elites supported the rebel cause -- the overthrow of Mr. Aristide and the reconstitution of the army, which has always served the elites at the expense of its poor. 
 Many of Haiti's poor -- the millions who live on less than a dollar a day -- remain loyal to Mr. Aristide, who rose to power on his promises to deliver ''peace in the mind, peace in the belly.'' They wonder what role they will have in a new government. 
 ''Look at how we are living,'' said Sony Aurelien, a 33-year-old port inspector who lives in La Saline, the vast slum where Mr. Aristide served as a priest, gesturing at the open sewers overflowing with putrid garbage. ''With Aristide, for the first time we have started to live. I am the first one in my family to have a regular job. Aristide tried to lift us up, so America kidnapped him and took him away.'' 
 One model for Haiti today may be Liberia, the West African nation of former American slaves established with American support in 1821. 
 In Liberia, less then seven months ago, as rebels besieged the capital, 2,000 marines dropped anchor offshore and secured the airport for aid shipments. Small platoons patrolled the capital and quelled the rebels. In weeks, they handed off power to United Nations peacekeepers. Liberia is hardly healed, but $500 million worth of promised international aid and the peacekeepers have made a start.
 Without law and order and a flood of economic aid, thousands more Haitian refugees may take to the seas, fleeing their failed state for Florida. The last time Haiti fell to an armed rebellion, in 1991, some 40,000 refugees washed up on American shores. During February, 1076 Haitians were intercepted by the United States Coast Guard.
 Stopping refugees was a high priority in dispatching the Marines. ''We will turn back any refugee that attempts to reach our shores,'' President Bush said.
 Some of those trying to flee Haiti are Aristide loyalists who fear for their lives. International law forbids returning political refugees to a place where they might be killed or jailed. In 1994, President Clinton created a ''safe haven'' for Haitian refugees at the nearby American naval base at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba. That base is now filled with suspected Islamic militants imprisoned by the United States.
 Hunger and disease are rampant in Haiti, and the flow of international aid achingly slow. Many international aid agencies' stores were looted during the rebel advance on the capital. ''We have let Haiti slip back into a silent humanitarian emergency even before this period of extreme internal strife,'' Jan Egeland, the United Nations's chief aid coordinator, told the Security Council on Friday.
 Saturday was market day in the capital, the first calm day for commerce in five weeks on the Rue des Miracles in downtown Port-au-Prince. But, given Haiti's ruined economy, ''normal is terrible,'' said Mona Alexis, a street vendor selling cinnamon, ginger and star anise alongside hawkers of brake fluid, saddle shoes and cornflakes on the Street of Miracles.
 ''I haven't sold a thing all day,'' said Ms. Alexis, 41, the sole supporter of five children. ''Nobody has any money. My family and I are barely surviving.''
 United States military aircraft landed all Saturday afternoon at the international airport here, deepening the American presence in Haiti. They ranged from a 17-seat government executive jet to a gray hulking Air Force transport.
 The transport jet touched down and, with its engines still running, its nose cone tilted up. Two dozen marines, three carrying laptop computers along with their weapons, walked down a ramp, blinking and squinting in the harsh sun.
 United Nations officials plan to fly here next week to study Haiti's needs, Mr. Eckhard said. 
 A long international occupation of Haiti ''would be sad, but it's necessary,'' said Regine Santil, a Port-au-Prince shopkeeper. ''We have proved through the years that we are incapable of running this country. But didn't the Americans who brought Aristide back 10 years ago know that this day would come?''

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2427 words

HEADLINE: How To Keep Them Down On The Farm

BYLINE: By JENNIFER GOLDBLATT

DATELINE: PARAMUS 

 BODY:
THE forces that have eroded New Jersey farming beckon at Susan Joy's doorstep: The Garden State Parkway surges through the back of the 16-acre vegetable farm her grandfather started harvesting in the 1940's, and $700,000 homes peek through a veil of bony poplar trees on either side. Developers are constantly circling.
 But Ms. Joy is digging in for the long haul. Last year she opened her farm to community-supported agriculture, selling shares of her crops to local residents months before the first head of lettuce emerged from the ground, and distributing them each week from June to October.
 For Ms. Joy and about a dozen other landowners around the state who together own at least an estimated 950 acres of land, this arrangement secures a market for crops in the pre-season, when money is needed for seed and for repairing equipment. The people who buy into these farms get weekly infusions of fresh vegetables and flowers all season long: lettuce, snow peas, arugula in June, tomatoes, basil and peppers in August and pumpkins in October -- all harvested just hours before it is on their plates. 
 ''Being able to get it freshly picked, it was just wonderful,'' said Sharon Zukowski, a novelist from Hackensack who bought shares in Ms. Joy's farm. ''It just makes a huge difference in taste.''
 What's more, the swelling popularity of organic food has provided a lot of potential members for these farms, known as CSA, for community-supported agriculture. Sales of organic foods have been growing by about 20 percent each year since 1991, and consumers bought $13 billion of organic food at supermarkets last year, according to the Organic Consumers Association in Little Marais, Minn.
 These farms serve to forge close financial and emotional bonds between the farmers and their communities, which many hope could help make farming financially viable in the long term.
 ''People feel like they are in this with you, and they are,'' said Michael Baki, head gardener of the community-supported gardens at Genesis Farms in Warren County. ''Even just by the fact that they've taken the step to join, that's a big big thing.''
 So is this a bargain for consumers? Well, for people who find themselves drawn to places like Whole Foods several times a week, the answer is yes, particularly since organic foods tend to be more expensive than conventionally grown produce. In a survey conducted by Watershed Farm in Pennington in August 2002 -- a particularly dry season -- those who had paid $19 a week for a family share received produce that would have cost $80 at a natural food store.
 Last season, an individual share in the Watershed farm cost $295, which worked out to about $11.80 a week for the 25-week season. Most farmers say that if there are any complaints from their members, it is that they get too much food, not too little.
 At first, the concept of community-supported farming was difficult to grasp for Ms. Joy's 71-year-old father, Joseph, who had worked the fields in and around Paramus -- now an intensively developed shopping mecca -- for decades with his family, selling what they grew at a roadside stand and to small retail shops. Initially he scoffed at the idea that his daughter would be taking people's money up front.
 ''When I came to my father with this idea I probably aged him five years,'' said Ms. Joy, 41. ''I think he sweated all the way into July.''
 But to his surprise, 22 people bought shares last year for $599 apiece, showing up each week to pick up their crops, and the farm broke even on the season's harvest. For the first time in recent years, Joy Farms was not caught between bigger stores that only dealt with big wholesalers and smaller shops that did not need everything the farm had.
 ''This turned out to be the perfect mix,'' Ms. Joy said. 
 Scattered around the country there are an estimated 1,200 farms that practice community-supported agriculture and feed about 90,000 households. The Northeast has been a fertile environment for such arrangements because it has so many dense urban areas brimming with people who crave fresh food, and, perhaps, contact with a more primitive form of food shopping.
 ''Ironically that density of the population - the thing that conflicts with farming that creates the fertile environment,'' said Duane Perry, executive director of the Food Trust, a Philadelphia-based group that develops farmers' markets. ''The consumer is pretty much next door to the farmer.''
 Virtually all of these farms grow crops organically, without synthetic pesticides, fertilizers or other artificial additives. But outside of that, the farms are a diverse breed. They are as small as Ms. Joy's suburban startup and as expansive as Watershed Organic Farm, a sprawling 90-acre operation on a land reserve in Pennington, a borough of yawning hills just west of Princeton. Watershed is one of the largest in the country, with 2,600 members last season and a waiting list with 121 names.
 While most of these farmers serve their members from June to November, their schedules vary according to where they are and when their crops flourish. 
 Most community-supported farms plant a wide variety of fruits and vegetables. The Watershed Organic Farm offers 60 types of crops and 350 varieties, ranging from basil and broccoli to crimson and white, candy-striped Dolce Di Chioggia beets.
 Many farms allow members to pick some part of their shares directly from the fields. Some examples are strawberries, raspberries, snap peas and cherry tomatoes. And some deliver shares to remote pickup sites at farmers markets and health food stores for the convenience of members who can not make it out to the farms. 
 Share costs vary widely among the farms, from $275 for an individual share to $599 for a family-size allotment. The sizes of shares also vary each week, according to what crops are in season and how the farm has divided them up. 
 These arrangements create ties between farmers and customers that are deeply felt. In the good years, the farmers are happy to share their bounty; during lean harvests they are glad to have loyal supporters. Yes, there is stress making sure that the customers feel that they are getting a fair share of high-quality food, but farmers like the intimate connection with the families they're feeding.
 ''Delivering a box of vegetables to the back of the store isn't especially thrilling, nor is talking to produce managers who have no loyalty to you,'' said Elizabeth Henderson, co-author of ''Sharing the Harvest,'' (Chelsea Green Publishing, 1999) a book on community-supported agriculture. With this system, Ms. Henderson said: ''I know my members' children. I know their parents. It's very rich.'' 
 To be sure, this kind of agriculture has thrust farmers into roles they have not historically held, that of being retailers. It requires them to add customer service and face time to their production duties -- not always an easy transition.
 ''It can be difficult to devote yourself to the farm members but also to your crops and your soil,'' said Jim Kinsel, farm manager of Watershed Organic Farms. ''If I were to spend a minute with everybody, that would be 2,600 hours.''
 Watershed and other community-supported farms have tried to stay close to their members in other ways, with newsletters that alert members to what is happening in the fields and recipes to advise them how to cook some of the more obscure crops, like kohlrabi, a type of turnip cabbage originally harvested in northern Europe. Some have hotlines so members can find out what crops will be available in a given week. Many organize cooking classes and lectures. Each October, Genesis Farm invites members to help harvest the vegetables that will be stored for the winter, and puts on hayrides, pumpkin decorating and a potluck dinner. 
 Members relish the excuse to escape to a rural setting, far from the clutter of their urban lives.
 ''There's just something about going out to where you can see where the food is growing and see people picking it,'' said Amy Wagner, 36, of Ringoes, a member of Watershed farm. ''It's a real community-type of feel and a nice atmosphere. And I just feel like when it's organic and locally grown, as far as the vitamins, the quality of the produce is going to be as high as possible.'' 
 Farmers also have to spend a lot of time educating their members about what it means to eat seasonally. For many people who are accustomed to the convenience of supermarket shopping, where virtually any produce is available at any time of year and you can get salad washed, cut and in a bag, the learning curve is steep.
 ''A lot of people have unrealistic expectations,'' said Luanne Lohr, associate professor of agricultural and applied economics at the University of Georgia. ''They thought potatoes grow all year. They wanted their children and families to eat well, but a lot of times they didn't know what they were getting. Some things sounded exotic but then they got too much of it, and they didn't want to learn how to prepare it.''
 Susan Keymer and Juan George, who operate a 12-acre farm in Monmouth County, extensively interview potential members, making sure that they understand what comes out of the ground at what time of year.
 ''Some people were in love with the idea of being on a farm, but the reality of farming is beyond them,'' Mr. George said. ''It's not just a supermarket. They would come to me on the first day of May and ask where tomatoes and eggs are.'' 
 The farmers also go to great lengths to explain the risks of buying into farms, the realities of floods, droughts, groundhogs and rabbits that can delay and diminish crops.
 ''We're as up front as we can be about the variability and the whimsy of nature and how that impacts the availability of any given crop at any give time,'' said Leonard Pollara, who runs Upper Meadows Farms in Sussex County. ''I try to paint as stark a picture as I can.''
 Community-supported agriculture has grown steadily over the last two decades; its rise has been intertwined with mounting public appetite for organic food and growers' move toward direct marketing.
 This form of farming first emerged in the United States in 1986, organized by farmers who were concerned about pollution in the food supply, and helping small farms remain competitive. They had seen similar arrangements in Europe and were influenced by the principles of biodynamic agriculture asserted by Rudolf Steiner, an Austrian philosopher. Mr. Steiner emphasized the use of local land to feed the community and pairing the farmer with the consumer. He shunned the use of chemicals, and advocated running a farm with respect to its interaction with natural forces like light, fertility and planetary movements.
 And since the 1970's, community-supported farms have been part of a larger shift toward marketing directly to consumers. The hope is that by cultivating community-supported farms, farmers' markets, catalogs and even ''agritourism,'' farmers won't have to split their incomes with distributors, processors and retailers, and can reap larger returns on the food they grow. 
 On average, farmers get about 19 cents on every dollar consumers spend on their produce at retail stores, according to the United States Department of Agriculture's Economic Research Service. That is nearly half of what it was two decades ago. 
 For Mr. Pollara, selling shares in his farm was a last resort after years of struggling to sell organic buckwheat, tomatoes, oats and other commodities to restaurants and distributors. With so many other farmers growing and marketing the same crops, it was tough to get a premium on his products. 
 ''Before I threw in my towel for farming, I wanted to see if this would work,'' he said.
 So far, he said, it has. In fact, Mr. Pollara is expecting to sign up 75 to 100 members to his three-year-old community-supported farm, and is optimistic that he can recoup the $48,000 it takes to run the farm for a year.
 Many farmers say that they break even for the season, or make a small profit. The larger operations enjoy economies of scale, getting discounts by buying larger quantities of everything from seeds to compost. 
 And many operate roadside stands or sell to restaurants, alongside their members' shares. To make ends meet, some of those who run these farms have part-time jobs elsewhere. For instance, Ms. Joy works at a florist during the winter, and Ms. Keymer and Mr. George drive school buses in the off-season. 
 Many people hope that this form of agriculture will ultimately sustain small farms in the long term. But that is still an open question. The answer depends largely on whether consumers continue gravitating toward organic and locally grown foods, or whether they are ultimately pulled back to fast food and salad-in-a-bag culture.
 ''I don't think that it's a silver bullet,'' said Kathy Ruhf, project director at the Small Farm Institute, a nonprofit group in Belchertown, Mass. ''I think this is a market opportunity and has great promise for how producers and consumers of food products can relate. But it remains to be seen in terms of the bottom line whether CSA is more viable for small scale family farms than other creative ways that people are engaging in survival.''

A Growing Phenomenon

HEADLINE: Confessions of a Gas Tax Advocate

BYLINE: By LOUIS J. GAMBACCINI. 
Louis J. Gambaccini, a senior fellow at the Alan M. Voorhees Transportation Center, Rutgers University, is a former commissioner of the State Department of Transportation and a former general manager of PATH and Septa.

 BODY:
TWENTY-THREE years ago, in my last year as commissioner of Transportation in the administration of Gov. Brendan T. Byrne, I mounted a campaign to increase New Jersey's gas tax by five cents.
 At that time, in the midst of a major financing crisis, the case for the tax increase was compelling. New Jersey then ranked 17th from the lowest among the states in gas tax rate. 
 Today, it is the fourth lowest. Had the proposal then passed, more than $5 billion would have been raised and invested in improved highways and transit equipment and facilities. The increased tax would have barely been noticed in the intervening years in the midst of the steady run-up in the price of gasoline. 
 Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who succeeded Governor Byrne in 1981, continued efforts to deal with the transportation financing crisis. The governor, together with his creative Transportation commissioner, John Sheridan, succeeded in 1984 in winning bipartisan support for establishment of a transportation trust fund. The fund performed well for several years, but then became victim to year-by-year political expediency: excessive bonding, a commitment to projects of dubious necessity and the diversion of capital dollars to operations. Virtually depleted, the fund's dedicated revenue will shortly be sufficient only to cover debt service and will have negated the original intent of a pay-as-you-go revolving fund.
 In the last year, I had the privilege of serving on Governor McGreevey's blue ribbon Transportation Commission. The commission in its report, detailed the very considerable needs of transportation maintenance, operations and required expansion in capacity. It found that New Jersey had the most heavily traveled highways and one of the most extensive and effective transit systems in the nation. The commission looked at several options of scope and financing and, bowing to its sense of political reality, recommended the least costly, minimalist program. This minimal option required a 12.5-cent rise in the retail gas tax to insure the continued safety, efficiency and quality of transportation in the nation's most-affluent and densely populated state. 
 Consider this: 
 1. At the increased proposed rate of the gas tax, New Jersey would rise only to the mid-range of the other states and much of the revenue generated would be paid by out-of-state residents traveling through New Jersey. 
 2. For the owner of a midsize car who drives 15,000 miles a year, the increase in the tax would equal a cup of coffee a week -- or less than the price of a ticket to one Broadway show a year. 
 3. The tax is a ''user'' tax. That is, the taxpayer directly reaps the benefit of the investment in physical facilities and improved operations of highways, buses and trains made possible by the revenue generated. Commuters standing on crowded trains and drivers stuck in incessant and ever-growing traffic jams should be able to relate to the current problems and the severe need for relief. 
 4. More than most states, the extensive, mulitimodal transportation system of New Jersey is vital to the state's quality of life, and stimulates economic development and efficient movement of people and goods to facilitate growth and jobs. The nation's fourth-lowest gas tax simply cannot sustain one of the nation's most evolved highway and transit systems. 
 How do we protect against a repeat of the maladministration of the trust fund? The commission report strongly recommends a new structure of governance for transportation finance, including a new board charged with reviewing the priority of large projects to assure a sound cost/benefit basis and to certify annually the financial viability of the fund to protect the pay-as-you-go feature and its integrity as a revolving fund -- something akin to but less autonomous than the New York City Emergency Financial Control Board established in the 1970's to lead the city out of its fiscal crisis. 
 I believe that the gas tax proposal fell victim to a surge of premature, anti-tax assaults and that the public -- properly informed of the tradeoffs and assured of safeguards for the protection of future financial viability -- would recognize the proposal as sound public investment. 
 The alternative is to stand by and watch the steady and catastrophic deterioration of facilities, worsening traffic congestion and declining transit service. I can't help but believe that an informed public would support a bipartisan consensus to stabilize and improve New Jersey's vital transportation system.
