HEADLINE: Improving Home Improvement

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
''NOBODY trusts contractors,'' said Jim Quinn -- a contractor himself -- the co-owner of Thomas Murphy Associates in Port Washington, N.Y., which has been in business 15 years, ''and the process of getting contractors is sometimes a dicey game, because homeowners wonder if they can trust them.''
 While there may be no certainty of finding the perfect home improvement contractor, or of easing the stress and improving the outcome of the home improvement experience, there are some guideposts for the search. Interviews with home improvement veterans -- contractors, architects, regulatory officials and even home inspectors paid to cast a critical eye on the final results -- found some time-honored landmarks, and some surprises, on the road map to successfully completing projects with a minimum of pain and a maximum of satisfaction.
 Finding a good contractor is, of course, a key step. Others, according to professionals in various aspects of the home improvement world, include using an architect -- and sometimes an engineer -- for major projects, paying careful attention to the contract and spelling out in precise terms the materials to be used and the finishing touches to be applied to the job. 
 Homeowners spent $130.4 billion on remodeling in 2003, according to the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University, and those expenditures have been increasing. After rising by more than 10 percent in 2002, spending on home improvements increased another 7 percent last year, according to Kermit Baker, director of the Remodeling Futures Program of the Joint Center. And, Mr. Baker said, with an improving economy, home improvement expenditures are expected to rise again this year.
 The biggest worry for most homeowners contemplating improvement work -- first timers and even those who have been through the process before -- is finding a contractor. While there are many reputable contractors, experienced professionals whose skills are crucial in both major and routine jobs, the files of consumer agencies bulge with complaints about shoddy and dishonest work.
 The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs said that home improvement complaints continue to outnumber all other categories, with 700 registered by consumers last year. And the National Association of Attorneys General said that complaints about home improvement contractors outdistance all segments except auto businesses and phone companies. 
 Reni Erdos, New Jersey's consumer affairs director, said that in 2002 (the last year for which figures are available) 2,100 of the more than 18,000 written complaints received by her department were about home improvements. Such complaints are No. 1 among seniors, who are often ready targets of fly-by-night contractors, she said. 
 THE single most important step a homeowner can take in finding a contractor, authorities agree, is to make sure that the contractor has a license. In order to obtain a license, contractors must typically undergo a criminal history check, pass a written examination and pay a license fee -- and in some places, New York City and Nassau County among them, post a bond or pay into a trust fund that provides restitution to consumers victimized by shoddy or incomplete work. 
 ''A license is no guarantee that a contractor will always engage in proper business conduct,'' noted a spokeswoman in the city's consumer affairs department, ''but it gives that department the authority to act on behalf of the consumer.'' Between 1995 and 2001, the department paid out some $3.3 million in compensation to consumers, and last year it paid consumers $330,000, thanks to the trust fund.
 Various jurisdictions have different ways for consumers to check if a contractor is licensed. In New York City, consumers can telephone 311, the centralized service number, or go to www.nyc.gov/consumers. Westchester County lists licensed contractors, including the date their licenses expire, at www.westchestergov.com/consumer. That information can also be obtained by dialing (914) 995-2155. (A listing of similar contacts for other government agencies in the metropolitan area appears on this page.)
 C. Jaye Berger, a Manhattan lawyer, noted that it is a legal requirement in New York City that contractors be licensed. ''The absence of a Consumer Affairs license number on the contract,'' she said, ''is a red flag that this contractor is not a licensed company. And if he is licensed, he will be concerned about keeping the license.''
 Ms. Berger added: ''Make sure you have a good contract and have it reviewed by an attorney who knows this area of the law. Even sophisticated people often fail to have the contract reviewed before signing it.''
 Ms. Berger also said, ''Paying a contractor in cash is not a good idea, because it often winds up creating a dispute.''
 Before a contract with the contractor is signed, Ms. Berger and other specialists agreed, a homeowner would frequently be well advised to consult with an architect and possibly an engineer. ''One of the biggest mistakes the homeowner can make is leaving out the architect if one is needed,'' Ms. Berger said. 
 If the homeowner has not been clear in specifying everything he or she asked for and does not have an architect to convey those specifications to the contractor, she said, ''the results will come back to that homeowner in the form of change orders that will increase the price of the job agreed to in the contract.''
 Sherwood Dawson, who prefers to be called Woody, a builder for 28 years and then a home inspector for 18 years with an office in Cheshire, Conn., said that an architect would not generally be needed for a simple updating of a kitchen or bathroom, but should be hired for jobs that change the footprint of a home or significantly alter the plumbing or wiring. 
 On major projects for which bids are sought, an architect's blueprints and design documents are essential, he said, and the architect will usually put together a bid package, whose specifications will allow contractors to make complete and accurate bids. Homeowners should get prices from several contractors, he said. 
 ''If they don't have the architects draw up the blueprints and designs and the homeowner asks several contractors to bid on the job,'' Mr. Dawson said, ''most likely the winner would come in with extras -- for example, saying to the homeowner such things as, 'You didn't tell me you wanted a door here, this kind of material there and the number of lights there.'
 ''But if the same blueprints are given to each contractor, and if there's a dispute with a contractor because he didn't do what the client thought the contractor was supposed to do, if that contractor says it wasn't in the contract, he doesn't have a leg to stand on.''
 Mr. Dawson said the contract should contain a penalty clause in the event that the contractor fails to start or finish the project at the time specified. 
 Another desirable provision, Mr. Dawson said, is to stipulate that knowledgeable foremen will be on the job at all times to make sure that the project is being done properly. While that will increase costs, Mr. Dawson said, it may be a bargain compared with what the costs would be if the work is done without adequate supervision. 
 He added that the contract should also specify that the premises be swept up or otherwise left in good condition daily at quitting time. 
 Marcel de Winter, a registered architect in New York City, stressed the importance on major projects of a related profession, engineers. ''The first thing smart owners should do when they buy a home is get an engineer's report,'' he added, ''which should list the condition of the building and of its deficiencies.'' Mr. de Winter added that an engineer may also be valuable in a highly technical home improvement project.
 Generally, Mr. de Winter said, an architect will be knowledgeable about the feasibility of homeowners' plans and will examine zoning and code requirements before getting too far along in, for example, adding a swimming pool, a deck or another floor.
 JOHN MOSS, a building consultant and owner of Inspex Building Inspections in Jersey City, encourages homeowners to keep a watchful eye on the contractor performing the work. ''The homeowner should not be intimidated by the contractor,'' he said. ''He should stay on top of the project as often as possible to make sure that the work is performed properly.''
 Experience is one factor that may contribute to a satisfactory outcome. ''If I were hiring a contractor,'' Mr. Moss said, ''I'd want him to have at least 5 to 10 years of experience.'' 
 While contractors are the focus of most complaints about home improvement projects that turn out badly, homeowners may sometimes share the blame because they did inadequate homework before signing a contract. ''Homeowners should make sure the contractors are qualified to do the work they want done,'' said Walter Sedovic, an architect and the principal and chief executive of Walter Sedovic Architects in Irvington, N.Y. 
 In the case of a new roof, for example, manufacturers of newly advanced roofing materials require that the contractor be certified to know how to put the new materials on the roof, Mr. Sedovic said. 
 Several specialists said that contracts should go into precise detail on elements that the consumer has decided on. They should spell out, for example, exactly the type of windows that are to be installed or, in the case of hardwood floors, the kind of wood and the number of coats of finish on the wood. 
 Keith Steier, who owns Knockout Renovation in Brooklyn, said the client should accompany the contractor when picking out the materials. 
 Dana Williams, the director of concierge services for Coldwell Banker Hunt Kennedy offices in Manhattan, brings an especially experienced eye to the selection of contractors. In certain locations in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, Coldwell Banker offers homeowners referrals to local home improvement professionals -- a service provided free to people who have bought or sold homes through Coldwell Banker.
 Part of Ms. Williams's job is to pick contractors to recommend to clients. Once contractors have been referred to her, she personally examines their work and makes sure that they have liability insurance and that they also have workers' compensation insurance.
 MS. WILLIAMS said she also phoned the contractors' previous clients and asked them whether they were satisfied with the work and whether the workers left the house in good condition when they were on the job. 
 From the contractors themselves, she asks how long they have been in the business and what their employee turnover rates are. 
 The flip side of the coin of finding good contractors, of course, is avoiding bad ones. George A. Gardner, the director of consumer affairs for Suffolk County, said that his office periodically posts the names of contractors about whom complaints have been filed in the Consumer Affairs Department's section (under the heading ''Worst Unlicensed Businesses'') on the county's Web site (www.co.suffolk.ny.us).
 Mr. Quinn, the contractor in Port Washington, said that such efforts may be helpful, but are not the complete answer. Speaking of the contractors listed on Suffolk's Web site and other similar lists, Mr. Quinn said: ''They're like the worst of the worst, because to get to a point where their license is actually taken away, they have to be terrible people. But there are a lot of others like them out there that are not on the list that would be just as harmful.''

Checking on Contractors
 For those contemplating home improvement projects, help is available from myriad sources. Much of it is aimed at providing information to help homeowners approach a project. Some, however, especially from government agencies, is designed to help homeowners avoid dishonest or unsatisfactory contractors.
 Sources of home improvement advice include the Web site of the National Association of the Remodeling Industry (www.remodeltoday.com). Individual contractors also frequently have Web sites that show their work, and sometimes have general useful information. Home improvement advice is also sometimes available in home centers and large hardware stores. 
 * Information on whether contractors who perform remodeling or repair work on residential property in New York City are licensed is available on the city's Web site (www.nyc.gov/consumers) or through the 311 service telephone number. 
 * In Nassau County, similar information is available by telephoning the Office of Consumer Affairs at (516) 571-2600. Callers can also obtain a six-year history of any complaints lodged against contractors.
 * The Web site for Suffolk County (www.co.suffolk.ny.us) includes both a list of ''Worst Unlicensed Businesses,'' and a way of confirming that contractors are licensed. A section of the Consumer Affairs Department's pages on the site, under ''Licensing Bureau,'' allows a user to enter the phone number of a contractor. The site cautions, though, that if the contractor is not listed as being licensed, this should be verified with the Office of Consumer Affairs at (631) 853-4600. 
 * Westchester County, which requires that every home improvement contractor be licensed, has a Web site (www.westchestergov.com/consumer) listing the names of 5,600 home improvement contractors and the expiration dates of their licenses. It also has databases for the last 10 to 15 years and a history of complaints and their resolution. Those histories are not available on the Web site; they can be obtained only by sending a request by e-mail, fax or telephone at (914) 995-2155, and the histories will be mailed to the consumers. 
 * Rockland County's Department of Consumer Protection is available by telephone at (845) 364-2680. A representative will use its computer system to look up information about contractors and report whether they have licenses and whether they have had complaints to deal with. 
 * Connecticut's Department of Consumer Protection has a Web site to provide home improvement information for consumers and information about contractors' licenses and any complaints (www.state.ct.us/dcp). The information is also available by telephone at (860) 713-6125. 
 * New Jersey's Division of Consumer Affairs does not list contractors on its Web site, but a spokeswoman said callers to the Consumer Service Center could give the name of a contractor and find whether any disciplinary action had been taken against the company. The number is (800) 242-5846 within the state, and (973) 504-6200 from elsewhere. EDWIN McDOWELL

HEADLINE: Crowds, at Last, at a Hard-Luck Hotel

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS. 
E-mail: amh@nytimes.com

 BODY:
THE Regent Wall Street was one of the city's shorter-lived hotels. It opened in December 1999 and closed on Jan. 17, 2004, a victim of 9/11 and a sagging economy. In its last incarnation, it became a glamorous symbol of the excesses of the roaring 90's, just before the market peaked and the Internet bubble burst. Peter Jennings, the anchorman, was married there; so, less auspiciously, were Liza Minnelli and David Gest.
 But the last guests to walk through the massive bronze doors were a motley crew of lonely hearts: people facing divorce; immigrant street peddlers trying to assemble a life in New York; penny pinchers; the unemployed; Wall Street lawyers and bankers tethered to their offices; people wandering the streets in search of human contact. 
 They had been invited, so to speak, to a giant liquidation sale of nearly all the hotel's furnishings, the intimate detritus of transient lives -- pillows gray from contact with hundreds, maybe thousands of heads; beds with gilded pineapple finials atop the bedposts; armoires too massive to fit in the average New York apartment. 
 The invitation, stapled to a sandwich board on the sidewalk outside, screamed: ''Five Star Hotel Contents! 2 Weeks Only!!'' It was an effective come-on. For the first three days of the sale, which was to end yesterday, so many people flocked into the 12,000-square-foot ballroom that the line stretched out the door. ''We didn't have time to eat lunch until maybe 4, 5 o'clock,'' said Edgar M. Castellon, who works for National Content Liquidators, an Ohio company that bills itself as ''The Nation's Premier Liquidator for the Lodging Industry.''
 Mr. Castellon, a soft-spoken Salvadoran immigrant, has liquidated the contents of many of America's finest hotels. Before New York, he was in Houston and Washington. In most places, customers are allowed to go right to the rooms to pick out what they want. But not here. In a city with few public toilets, the management didn't want people to be tempted by the facilities, so all the merchandise had been taken to the lobby. 
 You might think the liquidation business would be a sad line of work, capitalizing on the misfortune of bad business decisions, profiteering on the backs of unemployed bellhops and maids. This would be a misconception, insisted Mr. Castellon's colleague Frank Cucinelli. In his experience, most liquidation sales occur because hotel furniture goes through a lot of wear and tear and has to be replaced regularly.
 Even so, the mood this day was somber. Here was a banker in a dove-gray suit, scrutinizing a row of gold-framed hummingbird prints priced at $50 each, reduced from $65. ''Do you think it's worth it?'' he asked his companion. ''Oh, yes,'' she assured him. ''The frame and glass would cost at least $120.''
 ''I think this one has more yellow in it, which is a little more antiquey,'' the banker said, lining up two identical prints as his companion composed her face into an expression of studied agreeableness.
 The banker was undergoing what he called ''a marital separation'' from his wife of 15 years and was too humiliated to reveal his identity. Two months ago, he rented a garden apartment in Westchester County, to be near his three children, and he needed stuff to put in it. ''I probably would have moved back to the city if I didn't have kids,'' he said. So there are apartments in Westchester? ''Actually,'' he said, ''they do a nice cottage business with people like me.''
 What kind of decorating style did he have in mind? ''Eclectic, probably,'' he said. ''Birds, so this would fit.'' So he has other bird things? ''No,'' he said, frowning. ''Only this.'' He walked out $50 poorer, carrying his print swaddled in bubble-wrap.
 A bit later, a woman with white hair down to her waist asked: ''Do you have any spare lampshades?'' They didn't, but the woman had another thought. She planned to take one of the supersize $15 feather pillows, cut it in half and sew it into two pillows.
 Mr. Cucinelli, a former men's wear buyer lured out of his Florida retirement by the opportunities in hotel liquidation, concentrated on selling the nine-foot-tall armoires. ''They're all wood,'' he told a customer. ''That's a $3,500 piece. We're selling it for $600.'' What style would he say this was? Mr. Cucinelli faltered, but only for a second. ''I'd say this is antique reproductions of French and Italian artwork.'' 
 Ndiaga Diagne, a sidewalk vendor of New York T-shirts -- ''a licensed peddler,'' he stressed -- loaded a dolly with a king-size bed that he was taking home to Little Senegal, in central Harlem. Before the Regent slashed its rates after the terrorist attacks, guests paid $545 a night to sleep in this bed, $1,600 if it was in a suite. Being a street peddler, Mr. Diagne knows a good deal when he sees one. At $225, this bed was a steal.

HEADLINE: A Quiet Week (Except for That Verdict)

BYLINE: By JEFF SOMMER

 BODY:
While it was a stomach-churning week for shareholders of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, the stock market turned in modest, steady gains. 
 For the week, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 11.92 points, or 1 percent, to close at 1,156.86. 
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.63, or 0.11 percent, to close at 10,595.55. The Nasdaq composite index rose 17.81, or 0.88 percent, to close at 2,047.63. 
 The broader market rose on Friday after the government released a weak jobs report. It suggested to some investors that the Federal Reserve would keep interest rates low for months.
 The best return among the 30 Dow industrials, 6.48 percent for the week, belonged to McDonald's, which reported its biggest monthly sales gains since the 1970's.
 The stock of Ms. Stewart's company was among the most volatile. On Friday, until trading halted at 3:12 p.m., shares had risen 16 percent, to $17, on the expectation that Ms. Stewart would be acquitted of the charges against her. When trading resumed 30 minutes later, the shares plunged 36 percent, to $10.86. Ms. Stewart was convicted of conspiracy, obstruction of justice and making false statements in connection with the sale of shares of ImClone Systems in 2001. JEFF SOMMER

HEADLINE: The New Cost of Keeping Workers Happy

BYLINE: By DAVID KOEPPEL

 BODY:
EXECUTIVES have had their pick of job applicants during the sluggish employment market of the last several years. They have also found it easy to keep the employees they already have. 
 But a gradually improving economy could tempt more people to leave their jobs for better opportunities, according to employment and management consultants. That prospect is leading many senior executives to plan new enticements and perks to retain workers. 
 ''I think some employers are looking at a mass exodus,'' said Robert Morgan, president for employment solutions at Spherion, an international recruiting and outsourcing firm based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. In a survey conducted by Spherion in July last year, 51 percent of the 3,000 workers questioned said they wanted to leave their jobs, and 75 percent of that group said they were likely to leave within a year. In 1997, Mr. Morgan said, only 25 percent of the respondents expressed a desire to move on. 
 Turnover is extremely costly for companies. Spherion estimates that the turnover of one job, on average, costs a company 1.5 times an employee's annual salary, when separation costs, overtime payments to temporary workers, loss of productivity and replacement costs are considered. Some employment experts say employees' job dissatisfaction may have been driven by the layoffs of recent years. Joyce Gioia, president of the Herman Group, a management consulting firm in Greensboro, N.C., said that many employees who had managed to keep their jobs felt they were taken for granted and given increased workloads with little in rewards. Based on the Spherion study and several similar surveys, she said she expected that many workers who stayed in unsatisfying jobs during the economic downturn would leave as soon as they saw signs of a sustained economic recovery. 
 Some senior executives say the process has begun. Eric Bacolas, the senior vice president and global human resources director of Draft, a direct- and promotional-marketing agency based in New York, said that for the first time in several years, job candidates were becoming more selective and mentioning offers from other companies in interviews.
 Robert J. Puccio, vice president for associate services at Nationwide, the insurance and financial services company with about 32,000 employees, said that it was facing a possible ''war for talent'' this year. But unlike the late 1990's, when companies offered everything from massage therapists to space at work for employees' pets, employees will be more focused on work-life benefits like flexible schedules, telecommuting options and career planning assistance, he said. 
 Nationwide already has a fitness center at its headquarters in Columbus, Ohio, he said, and offers clubs geared to employees' interests -- whether in astronomy, bird watching, cameras or chess. In 2003, the company introduced a career-planning Web site, which provides information on company job opportunities, career development and the in-house mentoring service. 
 Mr. Puccio said Nationwide also offered opportunities to move within the organization's seven companies. About one-third of employees moved to other positions within the organization in 2003. 
 By the end of 2004, Mr. Puccio said, Nationwide plans to add classes and seminars that help employees with personal finance issues and 401(k) investments. Long-range plans include setting up an employee ''paid time-off bank,'' which lets workers accrue all their paid leave and then use it as they choose.
 ERNST & YOUNG, the accounting firm, is offering extra time off around holidays this year, according to Kevin Kelly, head of the firm's United States and Latin America human resources departments. Employees received a day off on the Friday before Martin Luther King's Birthday, creating a four-day weekend, and will also get extended time before Memorial Day and the Fourth of July.
 Executives at smaller companies are also trying ways to persuade workers to stay. 
 In 2003, Eisner Petrou & Associates, a public relations agency in Washington with 12 employees, had its first profitable year since 1999. Although David Petrou, the agency's co-owner and president, says he is still skeptical about the depth of the recovery, he hopes to hire two additional employees this year and to be able to give the remaining ones a raise of 5 to 6 percent. 
 ''With a firm this size, retention is crucial,'' he said. ''Our employees are our most tangible assets, so I try to make them feel vested in their jobs.'' 
 Some executives say they see no need to change the enticements they offer to employees. 
 Mr. Bacolas of Draft says his company has always tried to compensate its top performers well, and when possible, tries to give perks like free dinners or additional days off to overworked employees. 
 Similarly, Richard Smucker, president and co-chief executive of the J.M. Smucker Company, the maker of jams and preserves, said its retention strategy had not varied greatly over the years. 
 ''We do try to rotate jobs and offer people challenges,'' he said. ''We're constantly retooling our training program and trying new tactics. If our business is running well, then we don't have to put a lot of time into a retention program. That will take care of itself.''
 But other senior executives are trying new incentives to keep employees happy, particularly when they find it difficult to provide big bonuses and raises. In January, Dynegy, the energy company based in Houston, started an ''education in communities program'' that offered grants of up to $2,500 to schools, libraries and nonprofit educational programs selected by employees. One of the first projects is the addition of a nature trail for a Houston camp attended by mentally and physically disabled children.
 R. Blake Young, Dynegy's chief administrative officer, said the company planned to issue 40 grants this year. Employees submit the grant proposals, he said, and help execute the projects.

HEADLINE: Assessing California's Stopgap Bond Sale

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
LAST week, California voters approved a plan to deal with the state's budget deficit by selling $15 billion worth of new bonds. 
 William M. Fitzgerald, director of the fixed-income investment team at Nuveen Investments, talked last week about California and the municipal bond market. Following are excerpts from the conversation: 

Q. The new bond issue will buy California time. How has the state been coping with the shortfall until now?
 These are coming due as of June 30, and the state will use the proceeds of the bond sale to retire some of this short-term financing and remove it from their balance sheet.

Q. Will the state sell all the new bonds at once?

A. No, their plan is to sell it in tranches, with the first being a $6 billion issue. In large part, that is because the state treasurer believes that will be sufficient to finance what they need between now and June 30. That offering is due sometime in May.
 If they were to sell it all at once, a $15 billion bond issue would have an impact on the market and create excess supply. It would be the largest issue ever, eclipsing the $10 billion taxable issue sold by the State of Illinois in June of 2003.

Q. Six billion dollars sounds like a big number, too. Can the bond market handle it?

A. The $6 billion figure is reasonable to complete. In 2002 the California Department of Water Resources sold $6.3 billion worth of power revenue bonds as part of the solution to their power crisis. But they had to offer higher yields to get it sold.

Q. Will the state need to pay investors more in order to entice them to buy the bonds?

A. Currently, California general obligation bonds are trading at a spread of 50 basis points, or half a percentage point, above AAA-rated bonds of comparable maturity.
 There is a finite amount of California general obligation bonds that the market can absorb. I believe that California will be able to successfully issue the bonds, but they will need to appeal to a broad group of investors outside the state. 
 One element working in California's favor is that new issuance is expected to be down 15 percent this year from the last year's record-setting level.

Q. In addition to approving the bond deal, California voters also strengthened the requirement that state lawmakers balance future budgets. How difficult is it going to be to close the $14 billion hole they have in next year's budget?

A. They plan to close it by using $3 billion in proceeds from the bond issue that was just approved and cutting spending by $4.6 billion, which is 5 percent of the state budget.
 That still leaves them with a structural deficit of $6 billion. They expect growth in personal income tax revenues will help them bridge this significant gap. The state relies on personal income taxes for 45 percent of its revenues.
 Five percent is a lot of money to cut out of a budget. It will be interesting to see how and where Governor Schwarzenegger says he is going to cut spending.

Q. How realistic is the state budget plan?

A. The plan requires economic growth to be above trend.
 It is entirely possible that the state's projections could be realized if the national economy grows at a 4 percent rate or higher. But the longer-term growth rate for the country has been 3 percent. We would need to see a sustained period of growth of 4 percent or more to allow California to grow its way out of its budget problems.

Q. State and local governments across the country have been forced to deal with hard times. Has the improvement in the economy been a help?

A. In the fourth quarter, state and local governments experienced a 4.5 percent increase in revenues, after two years of steady declines. However, since their rainy-day funds have been pretty much depleted, at this point state and local governments are operating on very narrow margins. Any disruption in the recovery will cause them problems.

Q. Have the Bush administration's tax cuts made municipal bonds less attractive as an investment class?

A. One of the effects of the income tax cuts that the Bush administration has implemented has been a widening federal budget gap. That has raised the issuance of new Treasury bonds to finance the debt. And that has made municipal bonds look relatively more attractive. They have been a less volatile, more stable investment than Treasury securities.
 At the end of last year, yields on AAA-rated municipal bonds were 95 percent of Treasury yields. With the decline in muni supply and the increase in Treasury issuance, muni bond yields are at 85 percent of Treasury bond yields. We consider that to be fair value relative to Treasuries. 


A. Up until this point they have financed their deficit by issuing different forms of short-term bridge financing with maturities that generally are less than a year. They have issued $11 billion in warrants and $3 billion in revenue anticipation notes.

HEADLINE: They Can Make It There, but Some Prefer to Stay

BYLINE: By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
ALICE MURPHY, a college student from Huntington majoring in history and education, is not sure of her career yet. But whatever it is, she will probably not be working on Long Island, which she finds culturally impoverished, relative to New York.
 ''I like the atmosphere in Manhattan better,'' said Ms. Murphy, a junior at Goucher College in Baltimore. ''In Manhattan, after work you can go to museums, the opera, the ballet and the theater. On Long Island, you can go to the movies. That's about it.''
 When Karen Masri, 32, graduated from college nearly 10 years ago, she was certain that Manhattan offered the higher salaries and career mobility she wanted. Born in Great Neck, she started out as a chef and gravitated to Manhattan because, she said, that's where ''the restaurants are that get the publicity and where the chefs get the attention.'' 
 She has since changed careers and is now a stockbroker for Salomon Smith Barney in Midtown. But her opinion about Manhattan has not changed; it's still where she wants to be.
 Long before Walt Whitman left his native Long Island behind for an editing job at the old Brooklyn Eagle, ambitious young Long Islanders set off to pursue fame and success elsewhere. Last month, a well-publicized survey of Long Island's economic problems said this exodus had accelerated in the last decade, becoming one of the chief obstacles to economic growth.
 During the 1990's, the number of people in the 18-to-34 age bracket on Long Island dropped 20 percent, a rate five times the national average, according to the study, Long Island Index 2004, which was prepared by the Rauch Foundation in Garden City. The study linked the exodus primarily to rising housing costs.
 But interviews with young professionals and their employers found that the cost of housing is but one of a number of issues driving away recent college graduates. Those who leave do so for a variety of reasons, most commonly for higher pay, a greater array of social and romantic opportunities, and more flexible and youth-friendly housing. 
 Some also mentioned the prestige factor of working in Manhattan and the opportunity to compete in a national or international market that was not only much larger than Long Island's but, in the opinion of some, much more sophisticated.
 Others said that employment in fast-growing economies in other parts of the country promised a lower cost of living while maintaining a salary parity with Manhattan. Most Long Islanders said that although they could earn more money in Manhattan, they weighed other factors, like commuting time and not having to rely on public transit.
 Lawrence A. Israeloff, 40, a lawyer and accountant at Feldman, Meinberg & Company, a Syosset accounting firm, spent almost two decades working for law firms in Manhattan and did not like it. ''The commute was torture for me,'' he said. ''I took a 50 percent pay cut to be close to home. Now I work five minutes from home.''
 Mr. Israeloff has not regretted his decision. ''There is no amount of money that would be worth it for me to ride the Long Island Expressway through the tunnel again or to take the Long Island Rail Road again,'' he said. Still, the lower wage scales on Long Island irk him, he said, and in his view, Long Island employers are not attracting top talent because they pay less.
 Prestige, he said, is a significant factor. ''There are certain people who say, for example, 'I want to work for Skadden, Arps,''' he said, referring to Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, the Manhattan firm with 1,750 lawyers in 22 offices. ''Under no conditions would they work for a small Long Island firm.''
 ''The bottom line,'' he said, ''is that the most ambitious and competent people are going to Manhattan. Most people, I don't think would disagree with that.''
 Nicole Bardsley did. Ms. Bardsley, an account executive in her 20's at the EGC Group, an advertising agency in Hicksville, and a co-chairwoman of Fastrack, the Long Island Association's networking program for younger white-collar workers, said that professionals could make a name for themselves faster here than in Manhattan because Long Island companies were generally small enough for even entry-level employees to interact with industry leaders and make favorable impressions.
 ''Companies here don't have layers and layers of managers, so you have the opportunity to work closely with the principals'' of client companies, she said. 
 Jenny Lyn Georgiades, 30, an office designer for Waldner's Business Environments in Melville, said that having worked in both Manhattan and on Long Island, she found that Long Island offered a less stressful environment, in part because people seemed less competitive.
 On Long Island, she is able to arrange her schedule so that she can take kickboxing classes several times a week and can finish her M.B.A. degree at Adelphi on Saturdays. ''Had I still been working in the city,'' she said, ''I don't think I could have done this and still had a life or stable mental state.''
 Amy R. Burns, 33, an account manager for a Bay Shore software company she wouldn't name, said she could earn at least $10,000 a year more in base salary if she worked in Manhattan. But she would also face two more hours of travel time every day, commuting from Ronkonkoma, plus an extra $4,000 a year in travel expenses.
 The trade-off, in her view, would not be worth the cost. ''Trying to balance work and a family life is a little easier with a shorter commute,'' she said. ''With an infant son, I wouldn't be able to meet my work and parental responsibilities if I worked in the city.'' 
 Working on Long Island, she said, also fostered a sense of community. ''Your clients and co-workers are your neighbors,'' she said. ''You are making a difference in your community by putting money back into Long Island's economy.''
 Keshia Richmond, who owns Richmond Technology Solutions, a small software consulting company in Deer Park, said that the exodus of talented young workers from Long Island was indeed a reality, but not because of differences in pay. 
 Former employees, she said, complained about some of the very characteristics that Long Islanders consider attributes. For example, she said, Long Island's slower pace annoyed them, and the daily solo drives to and from work left them feeling isolated.
 While housing costs are high on Long Island, choices are also narrower than in some other markets, where young people can rent homes more easily, with roommates if need be, and be closer to urban centers for restaurants and entertainment.
 Limited social opportunities can make recruiting difficult, Ms. Richmond said. ''To get anywhere nearby for a happy hour, a power lunch, or just to hang out is usually a 20-minute drive in any direction,'' she said.
 Merrill Banks, the chief executive of Lloyd Staffing in Melville, the national employment services company, played down the fuss. Many of the young people now working elsewhere are going to return eventually, he said. 
 ''Many people work in the city because they know they have to have it on their resume,'' Mr. Banks said. ''They'll get paid more in the short run, and they're going to get paid more from Long Island companies after they have this experience.''

HEADLINE: Sorting Out Suffolk's Employee Drug Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID WINZELBERG

 BODY:
SUFFOLK COUNTY hired a consulting firm last year to audit an employee-benefits contractor even though county legislators knew the contractor was also a client of the consulting firm, and the arrangement is still in place 10 months after one legislator raised alarms about the apparent conflict of interest.
 The contractor being audited is Express Scripts, which operates the prescription drug plan for county employees. The county began the audit last June, officials said, after news reports of several lawsuits filed against Express Scripts and other benefits contractors by municipal governments and labor unions, accusing them of improprieties in the management of similar plans.
 The county gave the auditing assignment to Mercer Human Resource Consulting, a New York-based unit of MMC, the large international consulting firm. The county had been using another of MMC's subsidiaries, Marsh Inc., for advice on health insurance and other matters since November 2002. 
 One of the voices critical of Express Scripts last spring was David Bishop, a county legislator from North Babylon. In April, he introduced a resolution calling for an audit of the company to see whether it was retaining drug rebates and discounts for itself that properly belonged to the county.
 He also told fellow legislators that Express Scripts was a client of Mercer, and he raised the issue of whether Mercer should get the contract. 
 But the resolution was not passed. Mr. Bishop said it was blocked by opposition from police union leaders who served on a joint labor-management committee supervising the county's employee health plans. 
 Peter O'Leary, a former head of the union representing the county's police detectives and now a legislator from Shirley, was co-chairman of the committee last year. He said in an interview that the committee thought Mr. Bishop's proposal ''would be redundant'' because it had already decided to have Mercer conduct an audit of Express Scripts. 
 The health plan committee, which includes nine labor representatives and nine county officials, is responsible for the $175 million the county spends on employee health care annually. 
 Jeffrey Tempera, the county's labor relations director and one of the committee's current co-chairmen, said that no one from the consulting company told the committee about its relationship with Express Scripts in February 2002, when it first bid to work for the county, nor when it was hired nine months later. 
 When Mr. Bishop raised questions about the relationship last April, Mr. Tempera said, he asked the company about it, and he got a letter back from a company representative dated May 1, saying that ''Mercer is engaged by Express Scripts as a compensation and benefits consultant,'' but that ''we have no incentive, financial or otherwise, to recommend or favor a particular pharmacy benefit manager.'' 
 Satisfied with that answer, the committee decided to continue to use Mercer, though it put the matter under the scrutiny of the county's Joint Audit Committee, which includes the county comptroller, the county treasurer and budget directors for the legislature and the county executive.
 Asked for comment, Al Modugno, a spokesman for Marsh, said on March 2: ''We believe Mercer Human Resource Consulting's engagement for Suffolk County does not present a conflict. It is well known that Mercer, as well as others in our industry, frequently advises pharmacy benefit managers, and we disclosed this fact and the nature of our advice to Suffolk County in May 2003.'' 
 Nonetheless, Joseph Sawicki Jr., the county comptroller, indicated in an interview last week that he was not aware of the connection between Mercer and Express Scripts. ''If that's true, then this is very disturbing and certainly bears further scrutiny,'' Mr. Sawicki said. His staff has been overseeing Mercer's audit of the county's drug plan. 
 Mr. Bishop said that the Employee Medical Health Plan committee should not have allowed Mercer to continue with the audit. ''I don't know what they were thinking,'' he said. ''Their chosen referee was tainted.''
 Mr. Sawicki said that Mercer was still working on its audit of Express Scripts, and that its scope had widened, raising Mercer's estimate of the cost by more than half, to about $150,000. Even so, he said, the county is now doing parts of the job itself. 
 ''We had to expand the audit,'' he said. ''We want independent confirmations with pharmacies on what Express Scripts pays for prescriptions and what Express Scripts charges us, which we are doing on our own. That's how we recouped $2 million from the last drug plan.'' 
 An Express Scripts spokesman said the company expected the audit to endorse the quality of its work. ''We have facilitated audits by Suffolk County in the past and will continue to do so in the future, including the audit recently requested by the county's comptroller,'' the spokesman, Stephen Littlejohn, said. ''We fully expect this new audit, like all previous audits, to demonstrate that Express Scripts has complied with all contract terms and procedures.''
 Maury Herman, a partner in Herman, Mathis, Casey, Kitchens & Gerel, an Atlanta law firm involved in 23 lawsuits against Express Scripts and other benefit contractors around the country, said of the companies, ''They are the quintessential middleman, causing artificial inflation of prescription drugs when they are required to reduce the cost.'' 
 Mr. Littlejohn of Express Scripts said the company had helped Suffolk County keep the growth in its spending on prescription drugs below the national average. 
 Suffolk's new county executive, Steve Levy, proposed a review of the county's health plans ''from top to bottom'' in his budget resolution, scheduled for a vote in the legislature on March 23.

HEADLINE: Rutgers-Newark Prepares to Build Apartment Tower

BYLINE: By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
AFTER a promotional campaign about the benefits of learning in an urban environment, Rutgers University's campus in downtown Newark has sharply increased enrollment over the past three years -- a boon to both the school and the city.
 But attracting more students has also presented a problem, university officials say: where in Newark are the students to live?
 The city's business district has managed a comeback as a commercial office center, with a number of large buildings undergoing renovation and some new construction in the last five years. The six-year-old New Jersey Performing Arts Center has brought entertainment-seeking crowds back downtown. New housing, however, has not been part of the package. 
 A large number of single-family homes and subsidized apartments have been built in various redevelopment areas in recent years. But in downtown Newark, there has been little new rental housing since World War II, according to state and city planners.
 The New York-based Cogswell Realty Group and, earlier, the defunct New Newark Foundation have struggled mightily to find financial backers for a high-end rental housing project envisioned for two historic buildings adjacent to campus. Conventional lenders were loath to take a chance on the market for such housing, though.
 But Cogswell finally secured a commitment from the federally chartered mortgage finance company Fannie Mae, which announced in December that it would invest $42 million for converting the two deteriorated landmarks: the Hahne & Company department store building and an Art Deco office tower at 1180 Raymond Boulevard. The final pieces of the financing for that $95 million project are still being negotiated.
 Even if the project does move forward soon, it will not provide housing especially tailored to suit students. It will simply provide an option to those who can afford it.
 Meanwhile, as Rutgers-Newark's enrollment has increased by almost 10 percent in the last three years to an all-time high of 10,500 spring-semester students, the university resorted to some make-do solutions. Existing campus housing units were reconfigured to hold twice or three times as many students. Some students are being housed at the nearby campus of the New Jersey Institute of Technology, and about 80 students have been assigned rooms at the Robert Treat Hotel this year. Arrangements have already been made to expand the number of rooms to about 150 at the hotel next year.
 ''These are temporary fixes,'' said Steven Diner, the Rutgers-Newark provost. ''We don't think the growing popularity of Rutgers-Newark campus -- or our students' new appreciation for the city of Newark -- is temporary, however.''
 SO Rutgers, working in partnership with private developers, will build new housing for 600 of its students on its campus. ''What choice did we have?'' Mr. Diner asked with a laugh.
 The university's board of governors recently approved construction of a major new building on land that currently serves as a campus parking lot at the corner of University and Central Avenues. The 13-story complex, to be called University Square, will include several recreation areas and some street-level retail space.
 Mr. Diner said he was already talking with Cogswell about putting up a second student housing structure on another site on the 37-acre campus. 
 Beyond that, the university owns property in the nearby James Street neighborhood, where the city is planning mixed-use redevelopment, including housing, retail and office space. ''The university could be a part of that,'' Mr. Diner said. ''There could be housing that would be reserved for students along with development outside of the university's needs.''
 But right now, university administrators are focused on meeting the needs of their growing and changing student body, said Mr. Diner and others. The fact that enrollment hit a new high in the spring, when it usually slacks off from fall, means there will probably be another spike in September, said Gene Vincent, the executive vice provost for administration.
 In addition, the nature of the student body at Rutgers-Newark is changing, according to the administrators, with more full-time undergraduate students than in the past. Undergraduate enrollment is growing faster than graduate and law school enrollment -- although both of those are also increasing, Mr. Diner said.
 ''The campus used to be more commuter-oriented,'' he pointed out. ''There were more older and part-time students, who didn't necessarily need housing. Now we have students who say they want to come here -- but only if there is housing in the community.'' 
 Mr. Vincent said that ''University Square will provide a lively, urban, 24/7 atmosphere for the campus.'' He added, ''The location of University Square couldn't be more advantageous for our students, as it is situated just minutes away from the Newark Museum, NJPAC, Riverfront Stadium and downtown business.''
 Rutgers will retain ownership of the land on which the new tower will sit. The $51 million structure will be built and financed by the New Brunswick Development Company and the Keating Development Corporation, working as partners in a new company, the University Square Corporation. The new company is guaranteed to receive the rent from the building for a period of 30 years to pay for the cost of construction, Mr. Vincent said. After that, building ownership reverts to the university.
 ''This provides a way to avoid the issuance of university bonds to finance construction,'' Mr. Vincent said, ''which is definitely the way we wanted to go. This keeps the project off the university's balance sheet,'' so the risk is carried by the private companies rather than the taxpayers. 
 The university officers said Newark city officials had worked closely with them to get the University Square project through the approval process, helping to assure that construction can begin within months. The start of construction is tentatively scheduled for June, and the building is to be complete by the summer of 2006.
 THE Rutgers-Newark campus encompasses the Newark College of Arts and Sciences, University College, the Graduate School-Newark, Rutgers Business School, the School of Law-Newark, the College of Nursing, the School of Criminal Justice and a host of research and outreach centers. The campus is one of three that constitute Rutgers, the state university of New Jersey. The other campuses are in New Brunswick and Camden.
 Rutgers-Newark is bordered by two other universities -- the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and New Jersey Institute of Technology -- as well as by Essex County College, St. Michael's Medical Center and Newark's central business district.

HEADLINE: Why an S.E.C. Hurdle Won't Stop Fund Speculators

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT. 
Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a service of CBS MarketWatch. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE Securities and Exchange Commission proposed last month that mutual funds be required to charge shareholders a 2 percent fee on all sales made within five days of purchase. While such a fee might well discourage short-term trading, it would not help ordinary investors.
 That is because the proposal doesn't address the root of the problem: the stale pricing of funds. Stale prices result from the delay between the last trade of a fund's securities and the calculation of a fund's per-share value. Arbitrageurs have been able to exploit stale prices and profit at the expense of ordinary shareholders. 
 Gregory B. Kadlec, a finance professor at Virginia Tech, says the S.E.C. plan ''is like trying to stop a freight train by placing a penny on the railroad tracks,'' because arbitrageurs do not need to sell fund shares within five days to lock in a profit.
 Professor Kadlec bases his assessment on a study of stale prices he conducted in 1999 with John M.R. Chalmers, a finance professor at the University of Oregon, and Roger M. Edelen, a former finance professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and now managing director of research at ReFlow Inc., a firm that helps mutual funds manage the cost of inflows and outflows. In their research, they showed not only that stale-price arbitrage was profitable when holding periods exceeded five days, but also that speculators could increase profits by not selling immediately. 
 The professors' study appeared in December 2001 in The Journal of Finance after circulating as an academic working paper for more than a year. 
 To understand the researchers' argument, consider a Japanese stock fund that is based in the United States. Each day at 4 p.m. Eastern time, it calculates its net asset value based on the last trades of each stock it owns. Those prices are stale, of course, because they reflect the close of the Japanese market more than 12 hours earlier. 
 Stale prices give speculators a profit opportunity on days when economic news during the New York trading day is particularly good, and the United States stock market climbs sharply. On such days, the odds are high that the Japanese market will rise when it next opens. By buying the Japanese fund, speculators can invest in Japanese stocks at prices that prevailed before the good news was announced.
 In the debate about stale prices, many people assume that such a speculator would sell this fund the next day. Undoubtedly, many speculators do, so the S.E.C. rule would deter them. But the researchers suspect that hedge funds and other institutional arbitrageurs typically do not sell right away, and that their profit, on average, has been double that of those who do. 
 Speculators who don't exit immediately can sell short an equivalent dollar amount of Japanese stock index futures contracts. Those contracts, traded in Chicago, are not calculated using stale prices. That lets speculators sell at a fair price in the futures market what they are buying at an artificially low price through the mutual fund. The profit they lock in is the difference between the two prices.
 So long as this hedge remains in place, the speculators' profit is virtually assured. If the Japanese stock market declines, the short position in index futures should gain roughly the amount the mutual fund loses; if Japanese stocks rise, the mutual fund's gain should more or less equal the loss in the index futures position.
 This hedge allows speculators to sell their mutual funds on a day when the United States stock market falls significantly. That gives them another chance to profit, because the odds are high that the Japanese market will decline sharply when it next opens. By selling the Japanese fund, and simultaneously covering their short position, the speculators realize an additional profit, which the researchers have found to be roughly equal to what the speculators captured when they first bought the fund and shorted the index futures.
 THIS exit opportunity rarely comes within five days, the researchers found. But even if it did, the futures-based hedge lets speculators wait until a later day of market declines before leaving.
 Although data is not available, Mr. Edelen said he would be ''highly surprised'' if significant numbers of hedge funds and other arbitrageurs were not using this hedging strategy. He said the S.E.C.'s proposed rule would not curb their activities, even though their trading inflicts the greatest damage on long-term fund shareholders. Furthermore, he suspects that the rule might encourage more speculators to try the hedge, causing more harm to long-term shareholders.
 In proposing the fee redemption policy, the S.E.C. conceded that the ''principal solution'' to stale-price arbitrage ''is the accurate calculation of net asset value each day, using current and not stale prices.'' Mr. Edelen worries that a focus on redemption fees will divert attention from that goal.

HEADLINE: Art Throb

BYLINE: By Roberta Smith. 
Roberta Smith is an art critic for The Times.

 BODY:
These days, people like to say, art collecting is ''event driven.'' More and more, collectors aren't content simply to take in a gallery show, glide discreetly into the back room and buy something. Now they want an occasion -- buzz, options, competition, witnesses. They want their consumption to be conspicuous, to see and, more important, be seen, caught in the act of collecting at one of the chic art fairs held annually in places like Paris, Berlin, Basel, London and, more recently, Miami, where these photographs were taken. 
 How best to sum up these intoxicating, exhausting, signifier-steeped spectacles staged in vast convention halls that have the air quality of a trans-Atlantic flight? 
 Find out for yourself. Later this week, one of the largest, the nearly 200-booth Armory Show, will come to Piers 90 and 92 in Manhattan. Dealers and art will travel from as far away as Australia to participate. Even more surprising, a good portion of the Chelsea gallery scene will pack up and move a mere 30 blocks at untold cost in stress, shipping and indigestion. (The Armory Show is notorious for lousy food.)
 Starting Thursday night, the rituals will unfold. There will be the land-grab private view, where collectors beeline for specific dealers and artworks and then compare bounty, followed by the requisite gloating or promises to themselves to do better next time. There will be enough overt fashion statements to fuel several runway shows. And there will be untold parties, private dinners, photo ops and late-night debauching. 
 Art fairs have the sexiness, glamour and randomness of art auctions, except that they last for several days, which turns them into marathons. They used to be the art world's dirty secret -- dealers didn't talk about them; artists wouldn't be caught dead at them. Now they are at the forefront, increasingly central to the financial and social machinations of the international art world and the local economies that harbor them.
 Expensive and grueling as they are, many dealers participate in as many as four fairs a year and derive a large chunk of their income from them. They are such enormous information depots that critics and museum professionals can't in good conscience skip them. And artists, especially young ones, are increasingly visible as well. Sometimes they just hang out; often they stage installations or performance pieces that won't be seen anywhere else.
 But many artists still hate them, dreading phone calls from their dealers that begin, ''I'm going to Basel'' -- or Miami or Florence -- ''and I want you to give me something special for my booth.'' If an artist is successful enough to have a New York gallery and two or three out-of-town galleries all making the same phone call three or four times a year -- well, you do the math. ''I wish they would just go away,'' muttered one benighted soul.
 To everyone else, art fairs offer the convenience of one-stop shopping. They temporarily set the art world on fast forward, collapsing time and space, speeding up the acquisition of not only art but also reputations. Art fairs also eliminate, or at least reduce, the intimidating mandarin hush endemic to many galleries. This can be a major relief to novice collectors and the interested public alike, although certain dealers maintain imposing levels of hauteur in any environment.
 For denizens of the art world, fairs are also occasions for nonstop gossip and what might be called status assessment, especially in a fair's waning, or ''baby stroller,'' days, when most sales have been made and the fair is clogged with the nonbuying public. Who has the best art or the best-looking booth? (Design and vintage of desk and chairs are always taken into account.) Who has brought the largest staff or seems to be doing the most business? Who is making the biggest splash by resurrecting a golden oldie like Lucio Fontana or Alexander Calder, or introducing a hot young artist, or providing a custom-built video room with seating?
 Market shares are also parsed. Is Richter up and Kiefer down? Are the new Gurskys moving, and how fast and for how much? Is John Baldessari having a moment? And when does high visibility start to look desperate?
 An art fair is above all neutral territory, a kind of professional DMZ and not just for newcomers, or the rest of us, but for the dealers themselves. While demanding, art fairs offer dealers a grown-up version (sort of) of sleep-away camp, where they are forced into often surprisingly pleasurable intimacy with their own kind. Back home, art dealers don't spend much time in one another's galleries. This is because every gallery is a discrete universe, created from scratch by its owner and assiduously controlled down to the last detail. Dealers have trouble leaving the ''shop,'' as some affectionately call it, much less setting foot in someone else's. But at an art fair the playing field is relatively level and unfenced. All the dealers are facing the same challenges while suspended in the same anonymous, temporary setting, accompanied by a few carefully selected talismans from their worlds back home. 
 Maybe everyone is just being nice, but despite the competition, hours and bad air, something like camaraderie prevails. This, as much as the money changing hands and the art being proselytized, may account for an art fair's fizzy energy and cheer.
